It’s been an honor to get to know and support some amazing Democrats running up and down the ballot and all across the country.

You can get to know them too, right here—and if you’re inspired by their righteous fights, chip in or sign up to volunteer.
I know there are no words that can make the loss of someone you loved so deeply any less painful. My heart and my prayers are with you during this difficult time.
Trump and Pence are once again trying to downplay the seriousness of this pandemic just so they can look good. They’ve learned nothing from the devastating consequences of their mismanagement.
It’s an honor to be in this fight alongside you!

Oluwatoyin “Toyin” Salau was only 19. The news of her death is absolutely gut-wrenching.

She spent her last days fighting for justice. Now, we must commit to fighting for her. #JusticeForToyin

The people of NY-16 deserve an accountable, compassionate leader who will make their voices heard. I know that @JamaalBowmanNY will be a champion for working people in Washington and I’m honored to stand shoulder to shoulder with him in this fight.

The president is unqualified for many things—but giving medical advice is definitely near the top of the list.

As scientists and doctors work tirelessly to address COVID-19, the rest of us must be vigilant in holding Trump accountable for spreading dangerous disinformation.
It’s simple: Qualified immunity lets officers escape accountability when they violate constitutional rights. It needs to go—and if the Supreme Court won’t take it up, Congress must.

As we celebrate today's victory in the Supreme Court, let’s remember the activism of Black and Brown LGBTQ+ people that got us here.

The violence facing Black trans women is still a crisis—let’s keep fighting.

As a champion for fair wages, @ReverendWarnock has stood up for working families for years. I’m proud to endorse him because I know with him in the Senate, Georgians will have a leader with the courage and conviction to put working families first.

No one should have to live in fear of discrimination. The Supreme Court’s decision to uphold protections for LGBTQ+ workers preserves the LGBTQ+ movement’s hard-won progress—but we must keep up the pressure to ensure every LGBTQ+ person is free to be who they are without fear.

Donald Trump has endangered lives and eroded our democracy. We have to vote him out. But we also have to end the systemic racism that made his presidency—and the chaos and destruction his administration has inflicted—possible to begin with.

Our child care providers are part of the backbone of our economy—and they were among the hardest hit by COVID-19 closures. Protecting them must be part of any meaningful economic recovery. That’s what @TinaSmithMN and I are fighting for.

Remember: Steve Mnuchin is refusing to disclose which companies received more than $500 billion in taxpayer funds. Americans deserve to know whether this administration is serving working families, or just enriching corporate execs and wealthy friends.

It’s clear that Republicans will stop at nothing to suppress the people’s right to vote. That’s why we have to keep fighting to protect our democracy. 

Get your friends, family, and loved ones to join the fight for safe, easy, and accessible voting:

Mayor Bottoms is right to respond quickly to the death of #RayshardBrooks.

As a country, we need to address the use of deadly force within police departments. And we need to do it now.

On the anniversary of the Pulse massacre, the Trump administration stripped away health care protections for the LGBTQ+ community, putting millions of lives at risk. 

Congress must step up immediately to reverse this hateful and wrong decision.

Racist fanatics have sought to glorify slavery, white supremacy, and domestic terror through honors like naming military bases after Confederate leaders.

We need to root out white supremacy at every level. No exceptions.
We can’t rebuild our economy without taking concrete steps to stop the spread of COVID-19, like dramatically ramping up testing and establishing contact tracing programs nationwide.
Thank you @JoeBiden for committing to remove this racist legacy from our military assets.

Say their names: Dominique “Rem’mie” Fells and Riah Milton.

What we saw on Tuesday was not a free and fair election. And make no mistake: Republicans will use it as a blueprint to suppress the vote in November.

We need every level of government to secure voting protections—now.
I promise to keep fighting alongside you. For Drew, for Juan, and for everyone in this country touched by gun violence.

Four years ago, our country woke to learn of a horrific attack against the LGBTQ+ and Latinx community. I’m holding the Pulse victims and their loved ones in my heart today—and urge everyone to #HonorThemWithAction. Make a plan to vote and fight for change.

The Georgia election was a tragedy for our democracy. It’s the latest Republican attempt to suppress the vote—and another reminder of what could happen in November. 

Join the fight to demand safe and easy voting in your state:
The Trump administration’s failure to provide adequate, life-saving PPE for those on the front lines of this pandemic is worsening our nation’s response to this crisis and putting lives at risk.

Let's be clear: Sending guards to polling locations in Black and Brown neighborhoods, as well as Native communities, is a racist voter intimidation tactic. This is just part of the GOP's voter suppression strategy and we need to fight back.
We need to stop honoring these racist legacies—and continue to fight for bold, structural solutions to tackle generations of racial injustice and systemic discrimination head-on.
It's long past time to end the tributes to white supremacy on our military installations. And our work to reverse the legacy of white supremacy is just beginning.
Republicans who close their eyes, plug their ears, and sing "la la la" as Trump spreads conspiracy theories and misinformation are complicit in the erosion of our democracy.

Brian Kemp is sitting in Stacey Abrams’s chair because of voter suppression—and now under his watch, yet another election has been marred by dysfunction and disenfranchisement. We have to break our country's vicious cycle of voter suppression once and for all.

We saw it in Wisconsin back in April, and we saw it again yesterday in Georgia. Republicans will stop at nothing to suppress the right to vote—especially for Black communities and communities of color. This is not democracy.

What we saw in Georgia was the latest Republican attempt to suppress the vote—and another wake-up call heading into November. 

We need every level of government to secure protections now so that everyone can vote safely and easily. Join the fight:

Today, I’m handing over my Instagram account to @AlexisMcGill, Acting President of @PPAct. She’s spent her career fighting for reproductive rights and racial justice in America. I hope you’ll follow along! #ShareTheMicNow

This is the most critical election of our lifetimes—and Americans shouldn’t have to miss work, wait for hours, or risk their health to make their voices heard.

Demand your lawmakers take immediate action using our team’s easy tool:

Lines for hours, broken machines, systems down—this is not what democracy looks like.

We must ensure safe, easy, and accessible voting before this happens across the country in November and disenfranchises millions of voters.

We need voters to stay safe, not be silenced—and one simple way to do that is to allow all Americans to vote by mail, while also enhancing the safety of in-person voting. You can take action right now to ensure leaders protect the right to vote safely.

Congress needs to pass vote-by-mail, online registration, and in-person voting protections. But this fight also comes down to the states—and whether elected officials step up to protect our democracy during this crisis. We can't let up.
Georgia, please call @FairFightAction's voter protection hotline at 1-888-730-5816 if you run into problems while voting today. It’s more important than ever that your voices are heard.

As the Trump administration works to undermine the CFPB, states need to step up to protect consumers from financial fraud and abuse—especially during an economic crisis. @GavinNewsom must keep fighting to include this important proposal in the state budget.

Happening tonight at 7:30 PM ET!

Last year, I warned about the signs of another recession. Now, in the midst of a national pandemic, we're even more vulnerable to the devastating effects of an economic crisis. It’s long past time to build an economy that works for everyone.
.@AyannaPressley’s bold, principled leadership in Congress is more important than ever. I'm honored to fight alongside her and endorse her run for re-election.
Structural racism affects every part of our health care system—and this pandemic has only exacerbated the disparities that Black communities face.

Across the country people are assembling to demand our government listen and address the systemic racism killing Black Americans. This is a powerful moment in our history, and we should all be inspired by their determination that change is possible.

We’ve got 150 days until Election Day, and it's up to all of us to elect a leader who will fight for racial, social, and economic justice—and won’t traffic in fear and division or fan the flames of hate. Let’s get to work:

Eric Garner. Stephon Clark. Andrew Kearse. George Floyd.

Black lives matter. I’m proud to be @AyannaPressley’s partner in this fight.

On a recent Women for Biden call, I spoke about Breonna Taylor. 

Breonna should be alive today. And her story happens every day across this country—Black women and girls are brutalized at alarming rates.

This is an epidemic and we must call it out.

There is no one-and-done solution to the systemic racism deeply embedded in our policing and our criminal justice system. But it’s clear that Donald Trump won’t hold police departments accountable—so Congress needs to step up now.

I’m introducing legislation to reverse the Trump administration’s limits on the use of consent decrees, empower state AGs to pursue their own investigations into discriminatory policing, and triple funding for DOJ’s Civil Rights Division so they can pursue these cases.

We need systemic reform to address police brutality. But the federal government does have the power to investigate police departments with a history of discriminatory policing—a power that former AG Jeff Sessions severely constrained. Here's how we change that:
White Americans need to be active, anti-racist allies—in this moment and beyond. I hope you’ll join us for this conversation.

Breonna Taylor should still be alive and celebrating her 27th birthday today.

We must demand #JusticeForBre. Text ENOUGH to 55156.

We honor their lives by continuing the fight for justice. For George Floyd, Breonna Taylor, Ahmaud Arbery, Eric Garner, Stephon Clark, Sandra Bland, Philando Castile, and all the Black lives we've lost to racist violence.

Today, George Floyd's family prepares for the painful task of laying to rest their loved one. As a country, we honor the life of George Floyd and mourn all the Black lives we've lost to police brutality and a broken criminal justice system.

Police brutality threatens Black lives and our democracy. Every time activists and journalists are met with violence from the state, our fundamental rights are at stake. And any elected official who doesn’t take a stand is turning their back on our Constitution.

Let's be clear about what happened this week at the White House. The photo-op Trump wanted was not just of himself holding a Bible—he wanted footage of Americans who disagree with him being scattered, of violence pushed upon them. That's the photo-op he wanted.

This is just a start—and I’m in this for the long haul. Congress is responsible for holding this administration accountable—and anyone refusing to condemn their reckless, racist, and authoritarian actions shares responsibility for the consequences.

I’m also introducing an NDAA amendment to create an Office for Civil Rights at the Pentagon to hold the Department of Defense accountable when it violates Americans’ civil rights or discriminates against them based on race, ethnicity, or religion.

I'm supporting Tim Kaine’s NDAA amendment to ban the use of military force against civilians. We've seen too many weapons of war used against peaceful protestors and military forces patrolling our streets. It's morally reprehensible—and should be illegal.

We honor their lives by continuing the fight for justice. For George Floyd, Breonna Taylor, Ahmaud Arbery, Eric Garner, Stephon Clark, Sandra Bland, Philando Castile, and all the Black lives we've lost to racist violence.

Today, George Floyd's family prepares for the painful task of laying to rest their loved one. As a country, we honor the life of George Floyd and mourn all the Black lives we've lost to police brutality and a broken criminal justice system.

Police brutality threatens Black lives and our democracy. Every time activists and journalists are met with violence from the state, our fundamental rights are at stake. And any elected official who doesn’t take a stand is turning their back on our Constitution.

Let's be clear about what happened this week at the White House. The photo-op Trump wanted was not just of himself holding a Bible—he wanted footage of Americans who disagree with him being scattered, of violence pushed upon them. That's the photo-op he wanted.

This is just a start—and I’m in this for the long haul. Congress is responsible for holding this administration accountable—and anyone refusing to condemn their reckless, racist, and authoritarian actions shares responsibility for the consequences.

I’m also introducing an NDAA amendment to create an Office for Civil Rights at the Pentagon to hold the Department of Defense accountable when it violates Americans’ civil rights or discriminates against them based on race, ethnicity, or religion.

I'm supporting Tim Kaine’s NDAA amendment to ban the use of military force against civilians. We've seen too many weapons of war used against peaceful protestors and military forces patrolling our streets. It's morally reprehensible—and should be illegal.
I’ve also demanded an investigation into the role Department of Defense officials may have played in the attacks on protesters in Lafayette Square—as well as in protests across the country.
I’m calling for Barr’s resignation—and for an investigation into any Justice Department officials involved in this gross display of propaganda and the violence that preceded it.

Holding this morally bankrupt and relentlessly corrupt administration accountable is a critical job, and Congress needs to step up to the plate now more than ever.

Here’s how I’m working to demand answers and accountability this week:

Eric Garner and George Floyd should be alive today. It’s appalling that chokeholds are still classified as an acceptable use of force. I support @Hakeem_Jeffries's bill to outlaw them and @SenGillibrand’s Senate introduction of it—this is just a start.
Barr should be impeached and removed immediately—this recklessness is going to get more people killed.

We must keep fighting structural racism and we must be relentless in supporting organizations promoting racial justice and dismantling white supremacy. Here are few of those organizations—please donate if you’re able to.

Now more than ever, we need leaders who understand the root causes of the crises we face, and who are ready to make bold, progressive change. We need leaders like @Deb4CongressNM. She’s ready to stay in this fight, but she can’t do it alone—she needs your vote. 

Let’s do this!

The President of the United States tear-gassed peaceful protestors in order to clear the way for a useless photo-op outside the White House—just after vowing to activate the military against our own people. 

Lives and our democracy are in danger.

What this moment calls for is a president willing to lead—someone who will fight for justice and accountability with moral clarity when times get hard and people are in pain. Instead, we have a president who spreads lies, sows anger and division, and then runs and hides.

During LGBTQ+ Pride Month and always, we need to remember the Black Americans and LGBTQ+ people of color who put their bodies on the line so that others might be free. That fight is far from over. Let’s continue to fight against bigotry, hate, homophobia, and white supremacy.

If you’re able, donate to these organizations as they continue to fight for racial justice in America. This is a small first step, but every action we take adds up, and our response to this moment will shape our future.

We must be intentionally and relentlessly supporting Black communities and communities of color on the ground doing the critical work, day in and day out, to dismantle white supremacy across our country.

We need to ask ourselves what we are doing proactively to dismantle systemic racism in our communities, our workplaces, and our circles of influence. It’s not enough to stand as an ally. We must be anti-racist.

The idea that Black communities and people of color alone are responsible for fighting against racism every single day is misguided and can have dangerous consequences. White Americans have a serious responsibility, in this moment and beyond.
Congress must lead in this moment and demand accountability. I support Rep. @AyannaPressley’s resolution condemning police brutality, racial profiling, and use of excessive force.

There is a crisis within the crisis:

If we’re going to tackle this pandemic head-on, we can’t ignore its disproportionate effect on Black communities and the deep disparities that Black people have always faced in our health care system.

As a society we have some soul searching to do. But the deep injustices we face are not inevitable. They were created and facilitated through racist, hateful, bigoted public policies. That means they can be addressed by different policies—brave, inclusive, moral public policies.
This tragedy tears us apart. My prayer is that this atrocity can lead to greater understanding and ultimately the grace we all need to ensure justice for all.

The idea that communities of color alone are responsible for fighting racism is misguided and can have dangerous consequences. It’s not enough to stand as an ally. We must be anti-racist. White Americans must ask ourselves what we are doing every day to dismantle systemic racism.

We have to make real change in our country and fundamentally reform how the law is enforced in America. We need accountability for law enforcement and accountability at every stage of our criminal justice system.
I’ve also demanded an investigation into the role Department of Defense officials may have played in the attacks on protesters in Lafayette Square—as well as in protests across the country.
I’m calling for Barr’s resignation—and for an investigation into any Justice Department officials involved in this gross display of propaganda and the violence that preceded it.

Holding this morally bankrupt and relentlessly corrupt administration accountable is a critical job, and Congress needs to step up to the plate now more than ever.

Here’s how I’m working to demand answers and accountability this week:

Eric Garner and George Floyd should be alive today. It’s appalling that chokeholds are still classified as an acceptable use of force. I support @Hakeem_Jeffries's bill to outlaw them and @SenGillibrand’s Senate introduction of it—this is just a start.
Barr should be impeached and removed immediately—this recklessness is going to get more people killed.

We must keep fighting structural racism and we must be relentless in supporting organizations promoting racial justice and dismantling white supremacy. Here are few of those organizations—please donate if you’re able to.

Now more than ever, we need leaders who understand the root causes of the crises we face, and who are ready to make bold, progressive change. We need leaders like @Deb4CongressNM. She’s ready to stay in this fight, but she can’t do it alone—she needs your vote. 

Let’s do this!

The President of the United States tear-gassed peaceful protestors in order to clear the way for a useless photo-op outside the White House—just after vowing to activate the military against our own people. 

Lives and our democracy are in danger.

We have to make real change in our country and fundamentally reform how the law is enforced in America. We need accountability for law enforcement and accountability at every stage of our criminal justice system.

The racist violence that killed George Floyd, Ahmaud Arbery, and Breonna Taylor is not new in America. And what's captured on video represents only a fraction of the violence that Black Americans experience, some of it while in police custody.

Trump threatens American lives and American democracy. We need to vote him and his enablers out—but we must also commit ourselves to the work of dismantling structural racism and white supremacy in our country.

Donald Trump is calling for violence against Black Americans. His advocacy of illegal, state-sponsored killing is horrific. Politicians who refuse to condemn it share responsibility for the consequences.
The prison at Guantánamo Bay needs to be shut down—and in the meantime, we need immediate answers about how the Pentagon will protect everyone on base from COVID-19.
Donald Trump fires anyone who tries to hold him accountable. @JulianCastro and I agree: We need leadership in the White House that’s accountable to the American people.

100,000 people are dead.
1 in 4 people are unemployed.

Donald Trump’s response to this pandemic has been a leadership failure, a policy failure, and a moral failure of historic proportions.

Uber, Lyft, and Doordash have stockpiled $110 million to pass a misguided measure to avoid prosecution and protect their profits. Gig workers are struggling on the front lines of this pandemic—it’s time for us to show them whose side we’re on. I urge Californians to vote no.

Zuckerberg went on Fox News—a hate-for-profit machine that gives a megaphone to racists and conspiracy theorists—to talk about how social media platforms should essentially allow politicians to lie without consequences. This is eroding our democracy.

Lives and livelihoods are on the line. That means this is the most important election of our lifetimes. 

No one should be forced to choose between casting their vote and protecting their health. I’ll continue to fight to protect our right to vote safely.

It’s been a while since @JulianCastro and I had a chance to catch up, so today we’re going live on Instagram at 2:30 PM ET to talk about what working families are facing right now and why we need bold, progressive candidates to put people first. Hope you’ll join us!

Facebook’s annual meeting tomorrow may be the last chance to change these disastrous policies before we repeat the mistakes of 2016. Facebook’s own shareholders are demanding answers—and Mark Zuckerberg should listen to them and change course before it’s too late.
Last fall, my campaign demonstrated just how easy it is to pay Facebook to promote lies on its platform. This is unacceptable.

Facebook’s algorithm sows division and its ads policy allows politicians to lie without consequence, turning the platform into a disinformation-for-profit machine.

Refusing to change these policies is eroding our democracy—and it will only get worse.

I spoke with @ColorofChange about the painful impact of COVID-19 on the Black community and had the chance to address the horrific video of George Floyd pleading for his life.

He should still be alive. We need reform and accountability to bring an end to police brutality.
We’re live right now with @IndivisibleTeam, @Voces_Milwaukee, and @TheOtherMandela—tune in!

The federal government has failed to honor its promises to Indian Country for decades—and this crisis is no exception. I'm joining @Deb4CongressNM in the fight to ensure sovereign Native nations have the resources they need to protect their citizens.

It’s more important than ever to make our voices heard in our democracy—and local and state governments must step up to ensure we can do that safely and easily. 

Learn more about how you can help protect the right to vote safely in your state here:

We need voters to stay safe, not be silenced.

That’s why @IndivisibleTeam, @Voces_Milwaukee, @TheOtherMandela, and I are teaming up to protect the right to vote safely as we navigate this crisis.

Tune in to hear how you can help:

Memorial Day was always a special day in our family. All three of my brothers served, and I'll be forever grateful that they made it back home safely.

We owe our fallen service members and their families a debt that can never be repaid. I hope you have a meaningful Memorial Day.

Bailey and I are back to answer more kids’ questions about the coronavirus.

I hope to see you all there!

Making sure every American has access to easy and safe voting is one of the most important things we can do right now.

I’m proud to partner with @IndivisibleTeam for a virtual town hall on how to protect our right to vote safely during this pandemic.

The fight to protect free and fair elections is critical, and we’ll need elected officials at all levels of government to make voting safe and easy across the country. 

Find out how to take action in your state and join us in the fight.
That was fun—thanks for having me on #LovettOrLeaveIt, @JonLovett! Always happy to help answer questions on the importance of strong oversight in our government.

Voting is the backbone of our democracy—and elected officials must do everything they can to ensure that voters can stay safe and make their voices heard.

Over 95,000 Americans have died. Lines for food pantries are long. Our unemployment rate is the highest it’s ever been. But billionaires got $434 billion *richer* in the middle of a crisis.

It's long past time for the wealthy to pay their fair share.

If we don’t act, child care providers will be forced out of business—leaving parents with fewer options and potentially unable to return to work.

@TinaSmithMN and I have a plan to invest $50 billion to stabilize our child care system before it's too late.

Delta and JetBlue are violating the intent of the Payroll Support Program. If they want to take taxpayer money to bail out their corporations, then they need to protect workers’ jobs, pay, and benefits as the law intends.

The need to pass vote-by-mail and in-person voting protections in Congress is critical.

But this fight will also come down to the states—and whether elected officials step up to protect our democracy during this crisis.

Congratulations to Susan @MoranVote on flipping the Plymouth & Barnstable State Senate seat blue! Susan is ready to address the real economic challenges Massachusetts families face with meaningful policy solutions. I know she’ll represent her community with everything she’s got.

Congratulations to John @VelisForSenate on flipping his 2nd Hampden and Hampshire district blue! John is a change-maker with a lifelong commitment to public service, and he’ll keep up the fight for our working people, our veterans, and our kids.
The honor is all mine, Alessandra!
It’s an honor to join you in this fight, @yuhline!

Companies that get taxpayer bailout money should be required to keep their workers on payroll—and corporate execs who abuse these funds should be held accountable.

These candidates have proven they’ll fight for working people in our country—and we’re doing everything we can to support them. If you’re able, pitch in whatever you can and join us in the fight to help Democrats win everywhere.

.@HillaryScholten knows what it means to stand up for what's right, even at personal cost. I know that she will lead from her values and make real and lasting change for the people of West Michigan. That’s why I’m proud to stand by her side in this fight.

I’m proud to stand shoulder to shoulder with @CartwrightPA in his run for re-election to Congress. We need leaders who are not afraid to fight for working families. Northeastern Pennsylvania needs an experienced, forward-thinking leader like Matt as their representative.

I proudly endorse Chairman @JerryNadler in his run for re-election to Congress. His record shows that he doesn’t just know how to fight, he knows how to win. I’m honored to call Jerry a friend and someone I continue to work with on important legislation.

.@Biaggi4NY’s leadership in 2018 helped usher a wave of significant progressive victories in New York including in reproductive health, tenants’ rights, climate action, and immigrant rights. I’m proud to stand shoulder to shoulder with her in this fight.

At a time when working families are being squeezed to their breaking point, we need fighters in the Senate like @MJHegar who embody strength, courage, and an unwavering commitment to putting people first. I'm proud to endorse her in the fight to deliver real results for Texas.

From her famous filibuster on the Texas Senate floor for women's reproductive freedoms to working on the expansion of funding for public education, @WendyDavis has been fighting for working families for years—and I know she'll do the same in Congress. I'm proud to endorse her.

.@VoteGloriaJ knows firsthand the challenges that working families in Tennessee face. She will make sure no family goes broke paying for medical bills and will stand up to corrupt special interests. I'm proud to support her bid for re-election.

As we meet this moment of crisis, @SDGeorgette's proven track record of fighting climate change and expanding affordable housing will be indispensable in Congress. I’m proud to add my voice to the broad coalition supporting Georgette.

.@Michelle4Kansas is a fearless fighter who knows the value of standing up for working families. As mayor of Topeka, she has proven herself to be a public servant whose first priority is the people. I’m proud to endorse her to represent the people of KS-02 in Congress.

As a young Dreamer, @CatalinaCruzNY envisioned a bigger and brighter future for herself and for others—and today she is a fierce warrior for the structural change she envisioned. It is an honor to stand with Catalina in her fight for justice and equality.

It’s more important than ever to help elect leaders up and down the ballot who will champion bold reforms and put people first. Today, I’m proud to endorse another slate of candidates across the country. Take a look:
But I can’t do it alone. Sign on to keep up the fight to protect our Postal Service:

Donald Trump has threatened to veto any stimulus package that includes aid to the Postal Service, the most popular government agency in our country. We can't let Trump use this crisis to privatize or cripple the Postal Service—and I won’t stop fighting to protect it.

This virus doesn’t discriminate based on immigration status—and our response shouldn’t either. I look forward to joining @UnitedWeDream, @JulianCastro, and community leaders to discuss how COVID-19 has impacted undocumented and immigrant communities.

Coronavirus remains a threat but some big corporations are planning to end premium pay for essential workers on the front lines—all while increasing profits and boosting paychecks for their execs. It’s time to pass the Essential Workers Bill of Rights.

I’m proud to endorse Theresa @GreenfieldIowa in her run to represent Iowa in the United States Senate. Her life has been defined by hard work, determination, and resolve—I know she’ll put the needs of Iowa’s working families first.

The public deserves to know that their government is working for them—not corporate execs and their wealthy friends. Treasury and the Fed need to answer the questions posed by the Congressional Oversight Committee.

An Inspector General’s job is to serve as independent government oversight for the American people to ensure that hard-earned taxpayer money isn’t being misused. 

Anybody who fears this kind of oversight has something to hide.

Once again: You can’t just “re-open” our economy with a tweet. You need to do the work, day in and day out, to make sure that our communities can stay safe. And that means—to start—implementing programs like widespread testing and national contact tracing.

From investing in infrastructure and public housing to ending predatory lending fines and fees, @YuhLine leads the fight for change in Albany. At a time when important decisions for working families are being made at the state level, I’m proud to support her run for re-election.

.@Castro4Congress knows that to make change we need to build opportunity, not barriers. He is determined to build an America that works for everyone—not just the wealthy and well-connected. I'm proud to stand with Joaquin in this fight, and those to come.

.@LucyMcBath fights from the heart for the people of Georgia. As a mother and advocate, she's fought to keep our communities safe from gun violence, protect our health care, and keep our promises to veterans. I’m proud to endorse her in her run for re-election to Congress.

It’s more important than ever to help elect leaders up and down the ballot who will champion bold reforms and put people first. Today, I’m proud to endorse another slate of candidates across the country. Take a look:
But I can’t do it alone. Sign on to keep up the fight to protect our Postal Service:

Donald Trump has threatened to veto any stimulus package that includes aid to the Postal Service, the most popular government agency in our country. We can't let Trump use this crisis to privatize or cripple the Postal Service—and I won’t stop fighting to protect it.

This virus doesn’t discriminate based on immigration status—and our response shouldn’t either. I look forward to joining @UnitedWeDream, @JulianCastro, and community leaders to discuss how COVID-19 has impacted undocumented and immigrant communities.

Coronavirus remains a threat but some big corporations are planning to end premium pay for essential workers on the front lines—all while increasing profits and boosting paychecks for their execs. It’s time to pass the Essential Workers Bill of Rights.

We need big, structural change to defeat the climate crisis and build a government that works for people, not polluters. @EvergreenAction has a plan for that—a really big plan.

Last month, @RoKhanna and I called for an Essential Workers Bill of Rights to guarantee basic protections for workers on the front lines.

Thanks to your grassroots support, we’ve secured many of these key measures in the HEROES Act—and we won’t stop fighting until it’s law.
Every eligible American should have the option to vote by mail or to safely vote in-person.

We can’t rebuild our economy without first stopping the spread of COVID-19. House Democrats have already included pieces of Rep. @Andy_Levin and my national contact tracing plan in their proposed relief package—and Congress should do more.

As @JoeBiden and I have said, all members of Congress and government officials responsible for the recovery programs should be required to refuse to own or trade individual stocks while in office. We need strong protections from conflicts of interest.

We can’t allow companies to use this crisis to boost their profits and consolidate their power while crushing workers who are already struggling to make ends meet. 

Rep. @AOC and I are calling for a moratorium on big mergers and Congress should pass it.

While Jeff Bezos is on track to become the world’s first trillionaire in the middle of a pandemic, Amazon is ending overtime pay for warehouse and delivery workers on the front lines. This is immoral.

If we fail to act, more people will get sick, more people will die, and more people will go broke. 

The solutions are at our fingertips. This administration needs to stop playing politics and do their jobs.

We can't erase decades of inequality overnight, but we can start by making sure essential workers have the rights and protections they need.

My piece with @RoKhanna:

This crisis is disproportionately impacting women, especially women of color. 

We need to fight for bold changes to help those who need it most—during this crisis and beyond.

We’re running out of time to save lives—and the Trump administration has yet to come up with a plan. 

We need to ramp up testing, contact tracing, and other critical measures now in order to keep our communities safe and begin to restart our economy.

Donald Trump and his cronies are trying to undermine the postal service. 

Congress must shore up USPS so everyone can continue to receive the essential supplies they need and as many Americans as possible have the option to safely vote from home.
Sen. Patty Murray, Sen. Tina Smith, Rep. Rosa DeLauro, and I have partnered up to make sure that workers’ rights aren’t thrown off to the side because of a public health emergency.

Dr. Fauci is right. 

If we don't ramp up testing, if we don't get a national contact tracing program in place, and if we don't follow the social distancing guidelines, then the next wave of COVID-19 is going to cause even more unnecessary deaths.

We need to ramp up testing, contact tracing, and other critical measures immediately if we're going to avoid more preventable illness and death.

I’ll be joining @Maddow tonight to break down what I learned from Dr. Fauci today:

We do not have the coronavirus under control—and if we don’t respond adequately and immediately, we’re going to see a resurgence in the fall and winter.

Thank you @JoeBiden for committing to appoint a truly independent Inspector General and for tackling corruption head-on.

William Barr chose to play politics with Trump and his cronies over ensuring equal justice under law on day one—and never looked back. 

He should have resigned a long time ago.

We need vote by mail. We need online and same-day registration. We need early voting and extended voting hours. We need real money for governments to administer elections safely.

If we’re going to tackle this crisis head on, we can’t ignore its disproportionate effect on Black communities and the deep disparities in our health care system.

We need strong oversight. We need to hold the Trump administration accountable. 

The public deserves to know that their government is working for them during this pandemic and beyond—not corporate execs and their wealthy friends.
Congratulations @Leahgreenb and @ezralevin! I have no doubt that you will be excellent parents and will teach your little one to fight righteous fights. Can’t wait to meet him.

I’m demanding answers from Brian Miller about his ability to serve independently from an administration that seems to dodge transparency and accountability at every turn. I hope he comes prepared to answer these questions during today’s hearings.

In this role, Miller publicly brushed off requests from Congress for information during the impeachment proceedings and the White House Counsel’s office refused to cooperate with several other congressional requests.
In 2018, Miller joined the White House legal team, counseling Donald Trump on several issues, including the impeachment proceedings.

Let’s talk about Trump’s nominee for Special Inspector General for Pandemic Recovery. If confirmed, Brian Miller would be responsible for overseeing investigations into billions of dollars in loans from the $2 trillion coronavirus relief package.

I’m glad to see cities taking up the fight to make sure essential workers are getting the rights, protections, and compensation they deserve.

The @NYCcouncil should pass an Essential Workers Bill of Rights—and Congress should follow suit.

The Trump administration is privately projecting a steady rise in coronavirus deaths—while publicly encouraging states to open back up. 

This is shameful, even by their standards.

This pandemic has exposed the disparities that rural communities—especially rural communities of color—have to deal with every single day. 

In the richest country in the world, everyone deserves high-quality health care—no matter where they live.

Relief for student loan borrowers shouldn’t be left up to technicalities. 

We must cancel student loan debt—so people get the real relief they need during this crisis and beyond.

Nonmedical hospital workers are putting their lives on the line, but often have access to less protective gear than their coworkers. It's not enough to thank them—all essential workers should have the PPE they need to stay safe. #StandWithEssentialWorkers

Leilani Jordan was an essential worker who went out of her way to help elderly shoppers with their grocery needs. She risked her life to help others—we must do our part to honor her.

It’s long past time for Congress to pass an Essential Workers Bill of Rights.

The details of how this protective equipment is being distributed should not be kept secret. 

I'm demanding answers from the medical supply companies who are working with Jared Kushner on his secretive Project Airbridge.

This #TeacherAppreciationWeek comes at a time when teachers have gone above and beyond to make our kids feel safe and cared for in the middle of a global pandemic. 

Today, and every day, we thank you for answering the call to shape the minds of our future leaders.

Bailey and I are back to answer kids’ questions about the coronavirus!

Have a question for us from your little one? Send it here, and we’ll try to answer it next:

On today’s World Press Freedom Day, we’re reminded that freedom of the press is a foundational part of democracy—and one of the most important tools for holding our leaders to account. I will fight to protect the First Amendment.

If we’re going to reshape our country and our economy, we need to be willing to fight for bold, structural solutions to the problems we face as a nation. I’m grateful for the AAPI leaders across the country who are driving these fights in their communities.

Discrimination has consequences—but data erasure often serves to mask those consequences. In February, with input from AAPI community leaders and policy experts, I called for disaggregated data. Now, as we fight COVID-19, it’s more important than ever.

The AAPI community includes nearly 50 diverse racial and ethnic groups, but the data we gather today doesn’t capture the richness of the communities—or significant differences on key economic and social outcomes.

May is #AAPIHeritageMonth, an important time to celebrate and honor Asian American and Pacific Islander communities, leaders, and history. I’m grateful for the AAPI leaders across the country who are fighting for bold, progressive reforms in their communities and beyond.

I’ve said it before, and I’ll say it again: Donald Trump is our most corrupt president in modern history.

But he’s just the worst symptom of a corrupt system. It’s time to root out corruption at every level and make our government work for the people.

Real unemployment is soaring. But for many, our economy wasn’t working even before COVID-19. As we recover, we have the opportunity to create an economy that works for everyone. That begins with a government that is accountable to the people—and that is what we will deliver.

Every Trump administration official and business executive contemplating wasteful, corrupt deals and giveaways should hear us loud and clear: Donald Trump may wink and nod at this corruption, but we will not.

.@JoeBiden will appoint an Inspector General to review every CARES Act transaction currently evading serious scrutiny. Wasteful, corrupt deals will be rooted out and undone. Suspicious transactions will be referred to the Justice Department for investigation and prosecution.

If Congress and the Trump administration are unwilling to act now, then we will ensure that these changes are made in January 2021—both through new legislation and immediate executive commitments made by the @JoeBiden administration.

3️⃣ Oversight: Inspectors General should be shielded from removal except for “good cause” and whistleblowers must be protected. The Congressional Oversight Commission needs subpoena power and authority to oversee all aspects of recovery, including the Paycheck Protection Program.

2️⃣ Lobbying: It's time to close loopholes and require more extensive reporting. Big corporations that apply for or accept bailout funds should not be able to engage in political spending or use their resources and political clout to lobby for bailout legislation that helps them.

1️⃣ Conflicts of Interest: We need strong, vigorously enforced protections. For example, both of us have long refused to own or trade individual stocks while in office. That should be required of members of Congress and government officials responsible for the recovery programs.

As senators overseeing the executive branch and as executive officials answering to independent oversight, @JoeBiden and I know oversight is vital. As we both argued in the primary, we must end corruption and guarantee a government that works for the people.

The CARES Act imposed some oversight, but when he signed it, Trump said he’d ignore the law and prevent a new Inspector General from communicating with Congress. He then appointed a loyalist to that role and fired another IG independently designated to oversee the bailout.

Trump seems to think he can direct funding for the response to this crisis based on which politicians are nice to him, which states he's trying to win in November, and which businesses he wants to enrich—all without any accountability.

Government delivers best when its actions are fair, transparent, and accountable. Donald Trump’s approach to COVID-19 has been anything but—and we must take broad, urgent action to stop his administration’s corruption. Read my new op-ed with @JoeBiden:

When it comes to his handling of this pandemic, Donald Trump has a view on oversight: He doesn't want any.

Make no mistake: We will keep doing our jobs and holding him accountable for his botched response to a national crisis.

Jared Kushner shouldn’t be overseeing anything—much less part of a national response to this crisis.

We need a bold, actionable plan that prepares us for a post-coronavirus economy that keeps our communities safe—not a vision board from these two.

Happy birthday to my favorite actor @TheRock! 

Sending you and your beautiful family lots of love (and keep singing to Tia while she washes her hands).
Brief update from our birthday boy!

On this #MayDay, I’m proud to stand in solidarity with essential workers who are exercising their right to strike to demand fair wages and basic protections—especially when we're leaning on them most.
Millions of Americans were already spending more than 30% of their income on rent—and with more than 30 million now out of work, @JulianCastro is exactly right: We need #RentReliefNow.
This year, we learned Bailey really likes burritos. For his birthday today, we treated him to one with his name on it. Happy birthday, Bailey!
Thank your mom for me for putting people first. Sending her all my love during these uncertain times.

I stand in solidarity with all workers on strike this #MayDay. And you can #StandWithEssentialWorkers, too. 

Call your representative to demand they pass the Essential Workers Bill of Rights and step up to protect essential workers:

The halt on citizenship interviews and oath ceremonies may be preventing over 100,000 people from completing the naturalization process.

I’m joining @AmyKlobuchar and my colleagues to urge @USCIS to adopt tech solutions to keep this process going.
Hospitals are already facing shortages of critical supplies like masks, ventilators, and prescription drugs to fight COVID-19. Our federal government can help—and voters agree that it must.

Kevin is a respiratory therapist and a disabled veteran. He understands crisis, and he understands that our leadership’s response has been horrendous. I gave him a call to say thanks—and to share how we’re fighting to keep workers like him safe. #StandWithEssentialWorkers

Our country’s leadership is in crisis, and the need to elect Democrats up and down the ballot has never been more clear. If you’re able, please consider chipping in a few bucks before midnight to help—we can only do this together.

Donald Trump and his incompetent administration have botched a national response to this pandemic, and have yet to come up with a concrete plan for our economy. 

Congress must step up and provide the real solutions Americans desperately need.

These candidates are fighting their hearts out to win—and we’re doing everything we can to support them. 

If you’re able, pitch in whatever you can before tonight’s deadline and join the fight to help Democrats win everywhere:
I’m joining @BernieSanders, @PramilaJayapal, and @MarkPocan tonight at 7pm ET to talk about the priorities we’ll be fighting for in the next coronavirus relief package. I hope you’ll tune in!

Donald Trump still isn’t using the Defense Production Act to get our frontline workers the equipment they need. That’s why I’m partnering with @RepSchakowsky to propose a bill that would rapidly produce the equipment and supplies Americans are counting on.

This administration has endangered countless lives by spreading medical misinformation, denying supplies where they're needed most, and putting politics over public health every step of the way. 

This isn’t a great success story, Jared—it’s a historic failure.

All six of these women need our support to win Republican-held seats and help make sure we protect—and expand—our majority. We’re not just playing defense—we’re going on offense. Join the fight and split a donation today:

Christy Smith will fight for her constituents in CA-25 to lower the cost of prescription drugs, make health care more affordable, provide American workers access to paid sick leave, and ensure the needs of families come first.

We need Kara Eastman representing NE-2. She'll join the fights on protecting health care, tackling student debt, and taking on corporate power—with the passion and effectiveness that she's already shown as a social worker, a nonprofit leader, and a champion for change.

Jared Kushner shouldn’t be overseeing anything—much less part of a national response to this crisis.

We need a bold, actionable plan that prepares us for a post-coronavirus economy that keeps our communities safe—not a vision board from these two.

All six of these women need our support to win Republican-held seats and help make sure we protect—and expand—our majority. We’re not just playing defense—we’re going on offense. Join the fight and split a donation today:

Christy Smith will fight for her constituents in CA-25 to lower the cost of prescription drugs, make health care more affordable, provide American workers access to paid sick leave, and ensure the needs of families come first.

We need Kara Eastman representing NE-2. She'll join the fights on protecting health care, tackling student debt, and taking on corporate power—with the passion and effectiveness that she's already shown as a social worker, a nonprofit leader, and a champion for change.

As an Associate Justice of the Ho-Chunk Supreme Court, President of the Wausau School Board, a professor, and a lawyer, Tricia Zunker has the vision and courage Wisconsinites need during this crisis—and I'm proud to have her back in the special election in WI-7.

Celeste Williams is running to represent AR-3 because she believes no one should go broke because they get sick, that all people deserve access to a world class education, and that workers in America should be treated with dignity.

As an educator and former school board leader, Candace Valenzuela knows first-hand the struggles that working families face—especially in TX-24. I know she’ll be an unwavering force in Congress who will fight tirelessly for them both at home and in Washington.

Gina Ortiz-Jones will be a tireless champion for working families in Congress. She’ll stand up to corporate special interests and fight for quality, affordable health care, a fair and compassionate immigration system, and an economy that works for everyone. Let's do this, TX-23!

Protecting our House majority is critical. But if we're going to get this government working for the people, we have to expand that majority—not just maintain it.

If you can, please chip in to support these fantastic women running to defeat Republicans:

The voices of essential workers must be front and center. In just a moment I’ll be speaking live with @aijenpoo, @RoKhanna, and workers on the front lines. 

Tune in to join the conversation—and to join the fight for an Essential Workers Bill of Rights.

If we don’t step up and protect the mom-and-pop shops during this pandemic, companies and investors flush with cash will take this chance to gobble them up at a time when they’re most vulnerable.

@AOC and I are fighting to put a moratorium on big mergers.

The only way we ensure that these loans are going to the people who need them is by making sure there are real strings attached to protect our workers—because you better believe the Trump administration will do whatever it can to help its wealthy friends.

This virus doesn’t discriminate based on immigration status—and our response shouldn’t either. 

We need to make sure everyone gets the coronavirus aid and economic relief they deserve.

I got a note yesterday from Sarah, a nurse in Utah. She and her husband are health care workers who can't afford time off to care for their girls because of student loan debt. We need to cancel student debt—during this crisis and beyond.
The Trump administration’s process for distributing medical supplies appears to be driven by politics instead of public health—and we need answers.

Once again: If we’re only testing people with symptoms who make it to the hospital, then we are far from understanding this crisis.

We need to drastically ramp up testing—and we need to do it now.
Donald Trump has had an arsenal of tools at his disposal to prevent medical workers from having to make these gut-wrenching decisions—and he’s decided to not use them. This is appalling.

I’m fighting for essential workers like Christina—a critical care nurse for over 30 years who’s been using the same mask to care for infected patients for four nights in a row, because her hospital doesn’t have enough PPE. #StandWithEssentialWorkers

There is something fundamentally wrong when billionaires are getting richer in the middle of a pandemic while hospitals are struggling to find PPE, essential workers are left without protections, and millions of families are scrambling to make ends meet.

Economic inequity has given the big Wall Street investors and private equity firms an opportunity to gobble up small businesses at a time when they’re most vulnerable. We can’t let that happen—and @AOC and I are fighting to put a moratorium on these practices.

During this crisis, the last thing we need is large companies and predatory private equity firms buying out struggling small business owners. And as @AOC says, these practices would have decades-long consequences. I’m proud to be her partner in this fight.

Last year, we got to celebrate Bruce’s birthday at the same spot where I took him to lunch the first time he came to Houston to meet my family. This year, the celebration might have looked a little different—but it was still filled with love.

Happy birthday, sweetie!

I was glad to talk with @AOC today about the Essential Workers Bill of Rights.

We called it a Bill of Rights for a reason. This is the minimum. The basics. The people keeping this country going deserve dignity and respect.

And if you know someone who is an essential worker, share this post with them.

We are all depending on the sacrifices essential workers are making every day to keep our country safe and healthy. It’s time to #StandWithEssentialWorkers and demand an Essential Workers Bill of Rights:

This morning, @AyannaPressley, @Deb4CongressNM, @RoKhanna, and I got together to launch the #StandWithEssentialWorkers Day of Action—and we’re asking you to join us in the fight to protect our essential workers. 

Here’s our conversation if you missed it.

.@AyannaPressley, @Deb4CongressNM, @RoKhanna, and I are kicking off the #StandWithEssentialWorkers Day of Action. Tune in and find out how you can be a part of the movement to protect essential workers.

I’ll be joining @AOC live on Instagram at 2:30pm ET to talk more about how Congress needs to pass an Essential Workers Bill of Rights and how we must all #StandWithEssentialWorkers—today and every day.
I’ve been getting a lot of questions from kids about what’s going on with the coronavirus. Bailey and I thought we’d answer them together!
Donald Trump’s words matter because he is the president of the United States—and his words have consequences.
Thank you @TriciaForWI for calling this out: No one should have to choose between their health and their vote.
I look forward to joining @Deb4CongressNM, @AyannaPressley, and @RoKhanna for our #StandWithEssentialWorkers Day of Action kickoff on Monday at 10 AM ET—join us!

Reopening states too soon will come at the risk of losing progress we’ve made in slowing down the spread of coronavirus. 

Here’s a better option: A proactive plan to stop this virus in its tracks—and that includes establishing a nationwide contact tracing program.

It's vital that Congress hears from workers themselves about their experiences on the front lines leading our pandemic response. 

Share your story below and know that I will keep fighting for you as hard as I fight for my own family. #StandWithEssentialWorkers

Thank you, today and every day, for all you do, essential workers. You're keeping an uncertain nation afloat, and you deserve better. That’s exactly what we’re going to keep fighting for. 

Join us on Monday and #StandWithEssentialWorkers.
I am so sorry for your loss, Nelini. I’m in this fight with you and I promise you that I will keep fighting so that Congress will #PutPeopleFirst.

If you’re looking for ways to support our frontline workers and are able to do so, please consider donating to coronavirus relief funds like the ones set up by @DomesticWorkers, @FeedingAmerica, and @CDCFound. The only way we’ll get through this is if we do it together.

On #SOULSaturday, I’m joining @JoeBiden and thanking our essential workers who have always been the backbone of our nation’s response in times of crisis—and that’s even more true during the coronavirus pandemic.

The U.S. has used contact tracing to stop the spread of STDs and tuberculosis, and other countries have begun to use this tool to stop the spread of COVID-19. Congress must step up so we can stop chasing after this virus and start fighting it head-on.

Working with state, local, and tribal governments, the @CDCgov will coordinate a strategy to hire, train, and deploy contact tracers who explain to people that have been in close contact with infected patients what they need to do to stay safe while protecting their privacy.

To confront a national crisis, we need a proactive nationwide strategy—and the Trump administration is failing to come up with one. Rep. @Andy_Levin and I have laid out a plan for a national contact tracing program that will stop the virus in its tracks.
We need to #BreakUpBigTech. Pass it on.

I’ve been getting a lot of questions from kids about what’s going on with the coronavirus. Bailey and I thought we’d answer them together!
Donald Trump’s words matter because he is the president of the United States—and his words have consequences.

Reopening states too soon will come at the risk of losing progress we’ve made in slowing down the spread of coronavirus. 

Here’s a better option: A proactive plan to stop this virus in its tracks—and that includes establishing a nationwide contact tracing program.

It's vital that Congress hears from workers themselves about their experiences on the front lines leading our pandemic response. 

Share your story below and know that I will keep fighting for you as hard as I fight for my own family. #StandWithEssentialWorkers

Thank you, today and every day, for all you do, essential workers. You're keeping an uncertain nation afloat, and you deserve better. That’s exactly what we’re going to keep fighting for. 

Join us on Monday and #StandWithEssentialWorkers.
I am so sorry for your loss, Nelini. I’m in this fight with you and I promise you that I will keep fighting so that Congress will #PutPeopleFirst.

If you’re looking for ways to support our frontline workers and are able to do so, please consider donating to coronavirus relief funds like the ones set up by @DomesticWorkers, @FeedingAmerica, and @CDCFound. The only way we’ll get through this is if we do it together.

On #SOULSaturday, I’m joining @JoeBiden and thanking our essential workers who have always been the backbone of our nation’s response in times of crisis—and that’s even more true during the coronavirus pandemic.

The U.S. has used contact tracing to stop the spread of STDs and tuberculosis, and other countries have begun to use this tool to stop the spread of COVID-19. Congress must step up so we can stop chasing after this virus and start fighting it head-on.

Working with state, local, and tribal governments, the @CDCgov will coordinate a strategy to hire, train, and deploy contact tracers who explain to people that have been in close contact with infected patients what they need to do to stay safe while protecting their privacy.

To confront a national crisis, we need a proactive nationwide strategy—and the Trump administration is failing to come up with one. Rep. @Andy_Levin and I have laid out a plan for a national contact tracing program that will stop the virus in its tracks.
We need to #BreakUpBigTech. Pass it on.

This email from Courtney in Brooklyn stuck with me: “We’re waiting for our leadership to catch up to our values.”

We can’t rely on local heroes using their own means to make masks and supplies. We need the government to stand up a national manufacturing infrastructure.

There is a crisis within this crisis. 

Our response to this pandemic must center the unshakeable truth that racism, discrimination, and biases across our basic systems have left the Black community in greater danger during the coronavirus outbreak.

We shouldn’t be drinking or injecting disinfectants. Let's not further overwhelm our medical professionals—and let’s not take medical advice from someone who tried to convince America that the coronavirus was a hoax.

I’m grateful to the nurses and frontline staff who took care of him, but it’s hard to know that there was no family to hold his hand or to say “I love you” one more time—and no funeral for those of us who loved him to hold each other close. I'll miss you dearly my brother.
What made him extra special was his smile—quick and crooked, it always seemed to generate its own light, one that lit up everyone around him.

My oldest brother, Don Reed, died from coronavirus on Tuesday evening. He joined the Air Force at 19 and spent his career in the military, including five and a half years off and on in combat in Vietnam. He was charming and funny, a natural leader.

He's misled the public from the start. He's allocating resources based on which governors he likes best. His family and their cronies are making policy decisions in backroom deals. Enough is enough. We need an investigation into Trump's pandemic response.

Our health care, janitorial, delivery, mail, transportation, farm, grocery, and domestic workers are on the front lines of this pandemic. @RoKhanna and I are urging Congress to enact needed protections for them in the next coronavirus relief package.

Happy Easter Sunday!

Today, I’m remembering some of the lessons I learned in Sunday school at McFarlin Methodist Church in Oklahoma: By doing good and acting in service to one another, we can live a righteous life.

Thank you Principal Williams for making sure not only that our kids are fed, but also that they know they are loved and cared for. 

People like Principal Williams give me hope. This is how we’ll get through this—together.

Voters shouldn’t have to choose between participating in our democracy and keeping themselves safe. 

We need to ensure everyone can vote safely—and we can do so by expanding vote by mail, early voting, online registration, and more.

Farmworkers are on the front lines of this pandemic, ensuring our communities are fed—and the Trump administration wants to reward them by cutting their pay. This is shameful. 

Make no mistake: We will fight for farmworkers with everything we’ve got.

There have been too many reports of growing xenophobia against Asian Americans during this crisis. @MazieForHawaii, @TammyForIL, and I are asking the U.S. Commission on Civil Rights for help to stop these hateful attacks.
The Trump administration is failing health care workers and first responders. Our federal government must make sure that our medical professionals get the protective equipment they need.

Our postal service is on the verge of collapse. I’m calling on Congress to act swiftly to shore up USPS so that everyone can continue to receive essential medicines and supplies, and as many Americans as possible can vote from home. #SaveThePostOffice

This is exactly why we need to collect racial data nationwide. If we don't assess the racial disparities on testing and treatment, we won't be able to allocate resources to the communities who need it most and save lives.

Our country is in the middle of a public health crisis and an impending economic recession. 

Congress must end its recess and get back to work on the next coronavirus relief package—now. People’s lives and our democracy depend on it.

.@AyannaPressley, @EdMarkey, and I are demanding that @CMSgov release comprehensive data on COVID-19 testing, treatment, and fatalities by race and ethnicity. It’s essential to uncover disparities and ensure equal access to free testing and treatment.

Our political system has debated the role of government since the founding, but the time for cheap political shots at government is over. Government action is essential to save lives and to rescue our economy.

Ronald Reagan famously said that the most terrifying words in the English language are “I’m from the government and I’m here to help.”

In this crisis, we’ve seen that the most terrifying words are actually “We’re in a crisis and the government doesn’t have a plan to get us out.”
We need a surge in testing capacity—not an end to it. This decision is absolutely irresponsible and potentially deadly.

This is a good step. Other states should follow—and I’m calling on Congress to include vote by mail and other steps in the next coronavirus relief package to keep voters across the country safe and strengthen our democracy.

17 million people have filed for unemployment in the last three weeks. And that doesn’t take into account the people who have been unable to file. It’s time for Congress to get back to work on the government actions we need now to save lives and our economy.

Millions of people have lost their jobs—but business is booming for the lobbying industry. 

I will fight to break the grip that lobbyists have on Washington, and ensure the voices of people hurt by this crisis aren't drowned out by corporate interests.

The chaos and the attempt to suppress the vote in Wisconsin should be a wake-up call for everyone. Congress needs to act immediately—and I’ll fight to ensure that, in the next coronavirus relief package, we include steps to keep voters safe and strengthen our democracy.

Our health system is stretched to the brink. People of color are affected at disproportionate rates. Unemployment is approaching Depression-era levels. The scale of this crisis demands we do much more, much faster. The next round of policymaking must address these hard realities.

Coronavirus poses a threat to free and fair elections. 

We need vote by mail. We need online and same-day registration. We need extended early voting and hours. We need real money for governments to administer elections safely.

Taxpayer dollars must go to workers and state, local, and tribal governments first—not corporations. 

We need strong conflict-of-interest protections. We need a ban on political spending and lobbying by companies who get emergency assistance. We need better oversight.

People and small businesses must come first during our economic recovery. 

We need to keep workers employed. We need new price gouging laws and enforcement. We need to protect small businesses from predatory takeovers.

Frontline workers are putting their lives on the line. 

We need an Essential Workers Bill of Rights that includes paid leave, protective equipment, emergency safety standards, hazard pay, and collective bargaining.

Families need economic relief beyond cash payments.

We need to suspend consumer debt collection. We need a true moratorium on evictions and foreclosures. We need to cancel student loan debt. We need to keep child care providers afloat and increase Social Security benefits.

To contain this crisis, we need a surge in testing capacity. 

We need the government to be producing tests, PPE, drugs in shortage, and any future treatments that scientists develop—not in the thousands, but in the tens of millions.

We’ve debated the role of government since our founding—but the time for cheap political shots at government is over. 

Congress must end recess to get back to work on the direct government actions we need to save lives and our economy. Here are my ideas:

One of the many messages of Passover is hope over hardship. May Jewish communities around the country and around the world find joy this Passover—even though this year’s celebrations may look and feel very different. Chag Sameach.

Congress needs to act swiftly to fix the problems with this program and eliminate the cap on the total amount of money to keep workers employed. The government should guarantee that every small business that qualifies will get the help they desperately need—full stop.

The confusing process of applying for PPP puts an extra, unnecessary burden on small business owners. Even if they’re able to apply, some big banks have shut out small businesses from being able to receive these loans altogether.

Small business owners are pleading for help—but the Payment Protection Program created to help America’s small businesses stay afloat and keep their workers on payroll has been nothing but a fiasco since its launch.
That fight does not end today. We’ll continue it together in the Senate and keep working to hold the wealthy and well-connected accountable to the people.

Thank you @BernieSanders, for fighting so relentlessly for America’s working families during this campaign. Your fight for progressive ideas moved the conversation and charted a path for candidates and activists that will change the course of our country and party.

Coronavirus has exposed the conditions under which too many Americans work every day.

We need stronger unions.
We need to raise the wage.
We need safer work conditions.
We need health care for all.
We need paid leave.

Not just during this crisis—always.

What’s happening in Wisconsin is a disgrace.

During a pandemic we need voters to stay safe, not be silenced—and one simple way to do that is to allow all Americans to vote by mail, while also enhancing the safety of in-person voting.

Join the fight:

This pandemic isn’t just exposing the disparities that exist for communities of color—it’s making them worse. We need comprehensive racial data on the people who are being affected by COVID-19 so we can address these systemic problems head on.

This is outrageous. Americans are being asked to choose between participating in our democracy and keeping themselves safe. In the next coronavirus relief package, I’ll fight for a plan that ensures the health and safety of voters and protects our elections.

The task of protecting our democracy has never been more vital. Congress must do its part—and governors and state officials must also step up to protect our elections. Join our fight to make sure every American can vote safely in November:

Our government needs to act immediately to ensure elections can proceed safely, securely, and on-time. But Donald Trump and right-wing Republicans are already using the crisis to disenfranchise millions.

Finally, we must provide states with the resources they need to administer the vote and to keep poll workers safe. That means at least $4 billion for election administration, conditioned on states adopting specific measures that will protect voters and reduce barriers to voting.

We must also protect the integrity of our elections during this time of crisis by countering disinformation and bolstering election security. Congress must provide states with funding to guard against foreign threats, and voters should be able to track their ballot at every step.

States must also enhance the safety of in-person voting, as many voters may face greater obstacles to voting from home. All states should provide at least 30 days of early voting and extend voting hours to help prevent overcrowding and promote social distancing.

While badly needed, these reforms will put additional stress on the already teetering United States Postal Service. Congress needs to act swiftly to shore up USPS so that as many Americans as possible can vote from home.

Next, we need to make the process of casting a ballot easier and more accessible. States should mail every registered voter a ballot with pre-paid postage and waive requirements that undermine social distancing guidelines.

We must ensure that Americans can register to vote safely and easily. States must prevent voter purges and restore any voter whose name has been removed from the rolls since the pandemic began. Online and same-day registration should also be made available for everyone.

As federal, state, and local governments rightfully issue stay-at-home orders and encourage residents to practice social distancing to combat the virus, large-scale, in-person voting on election day could present serious risks to public health.

No American should have to choose between participating in our democracy and keeping themselves safe. In the next coronavirus relief package, I’m fighting for a plan to protect the health and safety of voters and strengthen our democracy for the long haul.

Trump’s unproven claims about hydroxychloroquine have already led to stockpiling, creating shortages for the physicians and patients who rely on the medication.

Medical misinformation is dangerous and Donald Trump has no business giving this advice.

It's pretty simple: We need a government that’s on the side of the people and can execute in times of crisis.

I talked to @jonfavs about what that kind of government could look like (because it's sure not what we have right now). Listen in!

Donald Trump and coal-lobbyist-turned-EPA-administrator Andrew Wheeler are using this crisis as a cover to roll back environmental laws. The government should be focused on protecting public health, not making it worse.

.@RichCordray’s thread is so important. If the government doesn’t step up and act now, consumers will fall victim to the financial industry’s most predatory practices—just like they did during the 2008 economic crisis.

Tackling the pandemic is about doing everything we can now to save lives and keep the economy on life support—but it's also about how we plan ahead and mobilize for a post-coronavirus economy. Here's my full conversation with @EzraKlein.
