Millions of workers face unpredictable schedules that can change dramatically day-to-day—even by the hour—with almost no advance warning. A third of workers involuntarily work part-time because they aren't assigned enough hours by giant corporations trying to keep costs down.

As corporations rake in larger profits, working families across the country are getting crushed by rising costs and wages that are barely budging. Adding to their challenges, many employers—especially in the retail and service industries—are using algorithms to assign schedules.

Unpredictable work schedules are leaving too many part-time workers with no control over their time and not enough hours to make ends meet. My Fair Workweek Plan will put power in the hands of part-time workers and help them control their schedules.
Our government and our economy are working great for the wealthy and the well-connected, but not so great for everyone else. Iowa City is ready to fight for the big, structural change we need!
True story: I was seven years old when I realized my name wasn't actually Betsy!

Monopolies aren't just bad for consumers, they're bad for workers, too. Amazon workers in the United States and around the world, alongside @ITUC, @UNIGlobalUnion, and a coalition of unions, show that when workers fight together, workers can win.

My daddy was a janitor. My mother worked the phones at Sears. America gave me the opportunity to become a public school teacher, a college professor, a senator, and a candidate for president of the United States. I'm fighting so that every kid can have those same opportunities.

Wages have barely budged, while the costs of housing, health care, and college have soared. If you're struggling to get by—you're not alone. We need big, structural change so that our economy and our government work for working people, not just the wealthy and well-connected.
I wish I could've given you the speech then, but I hope you take it to heart now. Take care of yourself—and stay strong out there.
Thank you so much for your question, Raelyn! We’ve got this. Stay strong out there.

Our nation is being held hostage by well-financed extremists who will never put the safety of the American people first. I stand with the activists protesting outside the Supreme Court. I'll fight to end gun violence and root out corruption in Washington.
I was asked at a town hall “if there was ever a time in your life where somebody you really looked up to maybe didn’t accept you as much?” Here’s my answer:
My goal is to get elected—but I plan to be the last American president to be elected by the Electoral College. I want my second term to be elected by direct vote.
Thank you, Marion! Our campaign is driven by this grassroots movement—and I'm so grateful for every single person who is in this fight.
I'm grateful for everyone who came out to our Waterloo town hall. This is how we're going to make big, structural change—together.

A majority of those living with HIV today are LGBTQ+ people from communities of color, who especially in the South, often face too many barriers to health care. We need to break down those barriers so everyone gets the care they need. #WorldAIDSDay

Trump cut taxes massively for his rich buddies, and now he wants to cut off and reduce SNAP benefits for millions of the poorest Americans. This is how corruption keeps Washington working for the wealthy and well-connected, but not for everyone else.
Tell Bear I can’t wait to make a pinkie promise with her tomorrow!
On #WorldAIDSDay, we gather to remember the many lives lost to the AIDS epidemic, we stand shoulder to shoulder with those who live today with HIV, and we recommit ourselves to ending this epidemic.

When Amelia was little, I helped her Brownie troop organize a ferocious effort to try to sell the most cookies in town. Loved meeting more Girl Scouts who are dreaming big, fighting hard (and earning some impressive badges). Go Girl Scouts!

We proved them wrong. I’m not afraid of a fight—even a big one.

We’re hours away from our November fundraising deadline.

If you haven’t already, will you chip in $3 or more to help reach our goal? With the first primaries and caucuses around the corner, I’m counting on you.

I wouldn’t ask if it weren’t important: Will you chip in $3 now before our fundraising deadline at midnight tonight?

Any amount you’re able to give helps open new field offices, hire organizers in early voting states, and train @TeamWarren volunteers.
Thank you, @RepSchakowsky! Together, I know we can make the big, structural change our country needs.

I love every minute of our photo lines. Every photo we take is a chance to talk with voters and listen to their stories. Since our lines get long, I change into sneakers beforehand—I call it my “Mr. Rogers moment.”

Our November fundraising deadline is tonight. For some candidates, it’s crunch time for swooping up big checks from wealthy donors and PACs.

Not me. #TeamWarren reaches fundraising goals one $3, $10, or $7 donation at a time. Will you chip in now?

I'm proud to have @PaaWeeRivera on my team every single day. I know that, together, we'll be able to work with Tribal Nations and indigenous peoples to build stronger communities and a brighter future.

Frank LaMere was a dedicated activist who left behind an incredible legacy. I'll keep fighting to carry on that legacy by strengthening the relationship between the federal government and Tribal Nations. #NativeAmericanHeritageMonth

On just about every issue we care about—from criminal justice to immigration, affordable housing, climate change, health care, and gun violence—money and influence are holding up widely popular policies.

If we want to make any progress, we must root out corruption in Washington.
Happy #SmallBusinessSaturday! I've got a plan to use $7 billion in funding grants to help entrepreneurs of color get their small businesses off the ground—and fully close the startup capital gap.

Tribal Nations must be able to protect their citizens from domestic violence by non-Native perpetrators. The Violence Against Women Act must be reauthorized and recognize Tribal Nations' inherent authority to prosecute non-Natives who commit these crimes.

I’m proud that the average contribution to our campaign is $26. That’s because our campaign is funded by small-dollar donors, not fancy fundraisers, billionaires, or PACs. 

Chip in now—$26, or $3, or whatever you can—to keep our movement growing.

It's a point I've made since my very first campaign: Nobody in this country got rich on their own. They relied on infrastructure we all paid for, employees we all paid to educate. So if you're successful, good for you—now pay it forward so everyone has a chance at success.

When a private equity firm acquired a doctors group, patients experienced more aggressive medical debt collection lawsuits. Wall Street shouldn't be profiting off of the poorest patients. We need to rein in Wall Street—and we need #MedicareForAll.

I got a high-quality public education for just $50 a semester—but that opportunity doesn't exist today. States invested less in our public colleges and shifted the burden onto students. 

I'm fighting for universal public college so every student has the opportunity to succeed.

Climate change is an existential threat, and it's going to take a grassroots movement ready to fight for big, structural change to defeat it. I'm standing with the young activists on #ClimateStrike today—stay strong in this fight!

America must uphold its commitments and promises to Tribal Nations and indigenous peoples—and give them a fighting chance to build stronger communities and a brighter future. I've got a plan for that. #NativeAmericanHeritageMonth

It worked. Eventually, everyone got back to eating and talking—and Aunt Max was never in charge of bringing the turkey again.

So no matter what cooking disasters, miscommunications, or accidents happen this Thanksgiving, smile, readjust, and try not to take it too seriously!

An uproar followed as everyone loudly explained that “bring the turkey” meant a cooked turkey. Aunt Max considered that, then laughed. She said we'd eat Thanksgiving dinner in layers—a Jell-O course, a potato course, a pie course—finishing with a turkey course, in about 6 hours.
The people of Chicago are fired up for big, structural change. And I promise: As president, I’ll fight for your families as hard as I fight for mine. Thank you, Chicago!

Despite the progress and medical advancements, we still have a lot of work to do to end the HIV/AIDS epidemic. I've got a plan to provide more resources to tackle this epidemic and begin publicly manufacturing PrEP in my first 100 days. #WorldAIDSDay

We’re hours away from our November fundraising deadline.

If you haven’t already, will you chip in $3 or more to help reach our goal? With the first primaries and caucuses around the corner, I’m counting on you.

I wouldn’t ask if it weren’t important: Will you chip in $3 now before our fundraising deadline at midnight tonight?

Any amount you’re able to give helps open new field offices, hire organizers in early voting states, and train @TeamWarren volunteers.
Thank you, @RepSchakowsky! Together, I know we can make the big, structural change our country needs.

I love every minute of our photo lines. Every photo we take is a chance to talk with voters and listen to their stories. Since our lines get long, I change into sneakers beforehand—I call it my “Mr. Rogers moment.”

Our November fundraising deadline is tonight. For some candidates, it’s crunch time for swooping up big checks from wealthy donors and PACs.

Not me. #TeamWarren reaches fundraising goals one $3, $10, or $7 donation at a time. Will you chip in now?

I'm proud to have @PaaWeeRivera on my team every single day. I know that, together, we'll be able to work with Tribal Nations and indigenous peoples to build stronger communities and a brighter future.

Frank LaMere was a dedicated activist who left behind an incredible legacy. I'll keep fighting to carry on that legacy by strengthening the relationship between the federal government and Tribal Nations. #NativeAmericanHeritageMonth

On just about every issue we care about—from criminal justice to immigration, affordable housing, climate change, health care, and gun violence—money and influence are holding up widely popular policies.

If we want to make any progress, we must root out corruption in Washington.
Happy #SmallBusinessSaturday! I've got a plan to use $7 billion in funding grants to help entrepreneurs of color get their small businesses off the ground—and fully close the startup capital gap.

Tribal Nations must be able to protect their citizens from domestic violence by non-Native perpetrators. The Violence Against Women Act must be reauthorized and recognize Tribal Nations' inherent authority to prosecute non-Natives who commit these crimes.

I’m proud that the average contribution to our campaign is $26. That’s because our campaign is funded by small-dollar donors, not fancy fundraisers, billionaires, or PACs. 

Chip in now—$26, or $3, or whatever you can—to keep our movement growing.

It's a point I've made since my very first campaign: Nobody in this country got rich on their own. They relied on infrastructure we all paid for, employees we all paid to educate. So if you're successful, good for you—now pay it forward so everyone has a chance at success.

When a private equity firm acquired a doctors group, patients experienced more aggressive medical debt collection lawsuits. Wall Street shouldn't be profiting off of the poorest patients. We need to rein in Wall Street—and we need #MedicareForAll.

I got a high-quality public education for just $50 a semester—but that opportunity doesn't exist today. States invested less in our public colleges and shifted the burden onto students. 

I'm fighting for universal public college so every student has the opportunity to succeed.

Climate change is an existential threat, and it's going to take a grassroots movement ready to fight for big, structural change to defeat it. I'm standing with the young activists on #ClimateStrike today—stay strong in this fight!

America must uphold its commitments and promises to Tribal Nations and indigenous peoples—and give them a fighting chance to build stronger communities and a brighter future. I've got a plan for that. #NativeAmericanHeritageMonth

It worked. Eventually, everyone got back to eating and talking—and Aunt Max was never in charge of bringing the turkey again.

So no matter what cooking disasters, miscommunications, or accidents happen this Thanksgiving, smile, readjust, and try not to take it too seriously!

An uproar followed as everyone loudly explained that “bring the turkey” meant a cooked turkey. Aunt Max considered that, then laughed. She said we'd eat Thanksgiving dinner in layers—a Jell-O course, a potato course, a pie course—finishing with a turkey course, in about 6 hours.

They burst through the front door, and Uncle Crowbar banged the heavy roaster on the kitchen countertop as people crowded around to see the turkey. With a flourish, Aunt Max lifted the lid, proclaiming, “Biggest Turkey Ever!”

Everyone jumped back. It was RAW.

My mother fretted and Aunt Alice fumed. The boys buzzed around trying to get a spoonful of this or a crust of that. Aunt Bee tried to keep everything in order. Still no Aunt Max. Then one of the boys spotted her coming up the walk with Uncle Crowbar (that name is another story).

Thanksgiving dinner was set for noon, and most of the family was there by mid-morning. The table was set. The sweet potato casseroles were out of the oven. The pies were on display. The Jell-O molds were out on special plates. Food was piled everywhere. But—no Aunt Max.

Aunt Max was funny and quick-talking. She never took anything too seriously, including time. And she wasn’t much of a cook, so the other sisters made sure that she was up to the task—peppering her with questions, making sure she'd get a big enough turkey.

Thanksgiving was always a big gathering in our family. The holiday brought in family from Texas, Arkansas, and Kansas. That meant LOTS of planning over who would bring what, how much, and so on.

One year, Aunt Max, my mother’s oldest sister, volunteered to bring the turkey.

I'm heartsick for Jesus Martinez Manon and his family. We must end this cruelty. No family should live in fear of having their loved ones torn away from them—on Thanksgiving or any day. When I'm president, we'll build a humane immigration system and treat immigrants with dignity.

This year, I'm grateful for my family, for the incredible opportunities I've had, for the many wonderful people I’ve met, and for the grassroots movement that is fighting alongside me. From my family to yours: Happy Thanksgiving!

We're so grateful for everyone who does necessary work over the holidays to keep us safe and healthy. But too many giant corporations shamefully choose profits over people by staying open on Thanksgiving. Retail workers deserve to spend time with their loved ones, too.
I told @IAForWarren that if it’s a fight between money and the power of a grassroots movement, I'm betting on the people.

This is appalling. Our government has a basic responsibility to protect its citizens from dangerous workplaces—not bend over backwards to absolve and protect giant corporations. Phillip Lee Terry and his family deserve justice.
Thank you @BlackWomxnFor and @MsPeoples for joining me in Atlanta last week. I'll fight shoulder to shoulder with you to put power and resources in the hands of the people.
Governor Northam, you have the opportunity to empower unions and working families. You should take it.
This is cruel and appalling. These students simply dreamed of getting the high-quality higher education America can offer. ICE deceived and entrapped them, just to deport them.
I'm proud to stand alongside @Deb4CongressNM in the fight to ensure that the United States honors its promises and commitments to Tribal Nations and indigenous peoples.
At its best, America is a place for big dreams and second chances. That’s what I’ve always fought for, and that’s the America I want us to build together.

The Trump administration's cruel and dangerous policies are putting children in danger and driving families apart. When I'm president, I'll end his racist policies and welcome immigrants and asylum seekers.

Presidential candidates typically do "call time"—also known as calling wealthy donors and asking for big checks.

Not me. Our campaign is funded by grassroots donors like you. Will you pitch in now?

Google recently hired a notorious union-busting firm—and yesterday, fired four employees who were organizing their colleagues and holding Google accountable. I stand with Rebecca Rivers and her colleagues. I’ll always fight to protect workers’ rights.

Monopolies are bad for consumers and our economy—and they're bad for employees, too.

But when workers build a grassroots movement and fight together to hold Big Tech companies like Amazon accountable, they can win.
Dream big, fight hard, put on your sweatshirt, and let’s get to work!

Yup, I’m tired of “Woe Is Me” billionaires too, @TrevorNoah. My #WealthTax will help families afford child care, college, and free an entire generation from student loan debt—and the billionaires will be just fine.

Some billionaires figured it might be cheaper to run for president than pay my #WealthTax. Well they don’t have the power of a grassroots movement—and in our democracy, I believe in the power of people over money.

Fighting for the #GreenNewDeal isn't just about fighting climate change. It's a commitment to building a better future for the working people of our country by creating millions of good union jobs. We can’t fight climate change with a low-wage economy.

We need to build a new farm economy that is truly open to all. I’ve listened to Black farmers and updated my plan to reflect their experiences. We must root out structural racism to ensure Black farmers succeed.

We need bold action now to pass the #GreenNewDeal, build a green new economy, and defeat the climate crisis—and I've got a plan for that. I'm proud to work alongside groups like @SunriseMvmt to build the grassroots movement we need to fight climate change.

After my daddy's heart attack, he couldn't work for a while. So my mother got a minimum wage job—and that job saved our house. She was scared, but she found the strength to do what needed to be done to save our family.

I’ve got a lot of plans to bring big, structural change to Washington. But first, there's one plan that makes it all possible: Making sure we hit our monthly fundraising goals.

Can I count on you to pitch in to our grassroots movement before midnight?

Private companies shouldn't be able to profit off of incarcerated people by charging them to read a book or video call their family. My plan for criminal justice reform will rein in this exploitation.
I've proposed the biggest and most progressive increase in Social Security benefits in nearly half a century—an immediate $200 monthly increase. Families need financial security.
Nominating top donors to be ambassadors undermines U.S. diplomacy and national security—and I’ve got a plan to end this practice.

Michael Bloomberg may think he doesn't need people to win this election—he just needs bags of money.

He’s wrong. That's why I'm investing in meeting thousands of voters, taking over 85,000 selfies, and building a grassroots movement that will fight for big, structural change.

Experts agree: Broad student debt cancellation would supercharge economic growth by freeing a generation crushed by debt. Candidates who oppose it should explain why punishing young people matters more than promoting home ownership and business creation.
We need public financing of our elections. But manipulating the rules to attack @WorkingFamilies and push them off the ballot is wrong.

The same communities that have borne the brunt of industrial pollution are also on the front lines of the climate crisis—and extreme weather events could put them at even greater risk. We have to end the climate crisis and clean up Superfund sites.
I'm in this fight because I want our kids to have a brighter future. That's a hope we all share, and I'm grateful to everyone in Manchester who is in this fight for big, structural change.

#TenYearChallenge

Federal Minimum Wage, 2009: $7.25
Federal Minimum Wage, 2019: $7.25

It's time to #RaiseTheWage.
Thank you, @NewFLMajority! I’m so proud to be fighting alongside you for big, structural change.

For months, the people of Hong Kong have taken to the streets to stand up for their rights. This weekend, they went to the ballot box and sent the powerful message that they want to keep their democracy—and Beijing must respect that.

Let’s be clear: Our government criminalizes too many things and sends too many people to jail. In a Warren administration, we will: 

☑️ Repeal the 1994 Crime Bill 
☑️ Legalize marijuana
☑️ Undo the legacy of the War on Drugs
☑️ End cash bail and private prisons

There have been 2,302 mass shootings in the United States since Sandy Hook. We shouldn't have to live like this. But unless we root out corruption in Washington, the gun lobby will always have a veto on any legislation to end the gun violence epidemic.

I support the students, organizers, and activists demanding accountability on climate action and more at #HarvardYale. Climate change is an existential threat, and we must take bold action to fight this crisis.

My heart is with @LucyMcBath today. Jordan Davis should be alive. We must call out the fact that Black Americans have borne the brunt of the gun violence tragedy in our country. I promise to fight my heart out—for justice for Jordan, and to end this epidemic.

This guy was Mick Mulvaney’s right-hand man in Congress. Now, he has a plum job as a payday loan lobbyist and is cozying up to Mulvaney to advance his clients’ interests.

In a Warren administration, we’ll stand up to lobbyists and the predatory loan industry.
It was great meeting you, Maddy. Thanks for being in this fight!

Mike Bloomberg is placing $34 million in TV ads in one week—the most of any presidential candidate in history.

That’s one way to pay less under my #WealthTax. Because in a Warren administration, he and his billionaire friends would finally have to pay their fair share.
I’m grateful to have you in this fight, @bjoewolf. Together, we’ll keep fighting to end the gun violence epidemic.

Unlike other candidates, I don’t host fancy fundraisers, I don’t take money from PACs, and I don’t cozy up to billionaires.

Instead, small-dollar donors are the backbone of our grassroots campaign. Donate whatever you can now, and join the fight!

Donald Trump is a walking, talking conflict of interest. It should be illegal for a president to twist the rules of our government to make themselves richer. Under my anti-corruption bill—the biggest since Watergate—it would be.

.@JayInslee is exactly right. The Keystone XL pipeline is a harmful project that locks us into further dependence on some of the dirtiest fossil fuels on the planet. We need clean energy and protection for tribal lands, not another crummy fossil fuel investment.
People who made it big should chip in to make sure that everyone else can make it, too.
When workers fight, workers win. Congratulations to @WUWFP employees on unionizing! Let’s keep fighting together to ensure that it’s quick and easy for everyone to join unions.

Iranians have taken to the streets to protest corruption and authoritarianism. This struggle must ultimately be fought and won by the people of Iran, but we support their demand for dignity, freedom to connect to the outside world, and right to peacefully demonstrate.

.@IndivisibleTeam carries out important work organizing activism across the country and making sure our voices are heard. I’m grateful for our thoughtful conversation yesterday about how we can keep moving our country forward.
I’m inspired by the people of Nashville who are building a grassroots movement to ban private prisons from their community. In a Warren administration, we’ll ban them at the federal level.

It should be quick and easy to join a union. Yet here’s another example of how the rich and powerful try to stop American workers from standing together. I stand shoulder-to-shoulder with the Bright Solar workers fired after unionizing with @IBEW. #1U
Grateful to be in this fight alongside you, @AyannaPressley!
Did I have a plan to get me, @DesusNice, and @TheKidMero out of the escape room? You bet.
Every presidential candidate should join us in pledging to end the practice of selling cushy diplomatic posts to wealthy donors.

Black history is American history.

The lessons of Black history—from the Atlanta washerwoman's strike, to Dorothy Bolden’s fight for domestic workers—will not be lost.

What an honor to be with @BlackWomxnFor and @AyannaPressley at @CAU last night.

This isn’t about drivers’ licenses or the Census. This is another cruel way that the Trump administration and Republicans are working to undercount, underfund, and take political power away from immigrant communities. We must fight back.
It's my honor to have @Deb4CongressNM, @KatiePorterOC, and @AyannaPressley as my Campaign Co-Chairs. Big structural change can't wait, and we'll fight for it—together.
This cruel, unnecessary policy will put asylum seekers at risk. Our laws and our values compel us to help those fleeing violence and oppression. I'll reverse this policy and welcome asylum seekers.

WeWork is laying off 2,400 employees—while its founder walks away with a massive $1.7 billion golden parachute.

This is another example of a rigged and corrupt system. I’m fighting my heart out to put power in the hands of American workers.

Let’s be clear: It’s time for our government to have a full-blown national conversation about reparations. We must be honest about our history, and do what’s right so that our nation can begin to heal. #AtlantaWithWarren

White supremacy, white nationalism, and corruption threaten to break our democracy beyond repair. Now more than ever, all of us must embrace the lessons of Black history to confront this challenge. #AtlantaWithWarren

Racism props up the rich and powerful, leaving them free to take more power for themselves. And the rich and powerful aren’t going to just give away their power. If we want power, we have to fight for it. #AtlantaWithWarren

Yes, there’s a lot at stake in this election, and I know people are scared. But the washerwomen were not afraid. Dorothy Bolden was not afraid. I am not afraid. And you can't be afraid, either.  #AtlantaWithWarren
From the boldness of Atlanta’s Washerwomen to the courage of Dorothy Bolden, Black history teaches us that the only way to win is to get in the fight.
Dorothy Bolden showed that one very determined woman—backed up by many people across this country—can deliver big structural change.
This isn’t about whether or not we start a fight. We’re already in a fight. This is about how we win.

We all know—and say—the names of those whose lives have been cut short with callous indifference by law enforcement. Let’s honor Aiyana Stanley-Jones, Rekia Boyd, Korryn Gaines, Sandra Bland, and Atatiana Jefferson by reforming our criminal justice system once and for all.
And there’s more. It’s time to live our values. Look at the four words etched above the Supreme Court: Equal Justice Under Law. But justice is not equal in America.
Voter suppression is just one more relic of Jim Crow, and we need to say so. That’s why I have a plan to strengthen voting in America. It starts with restoring the Voting Rights Act.

Right now, our democracy is broken. How do I know? Because Brian Kemp is sitting in @StaceyAbrams’ chair. And we are all grateful to Stacey for what she’s doing to make sure that never happens again in this country.

The federal government helped create the racial divide in this country through decades of active, state-sponsored discrimination and that means the federal government has an obligation to fix it. And I have a lot of plans for how we can begin to fix it together.
The 1994 crime bill exacerbated the mass incarceration that has locked up millions of Black men and women, many for the smallest infractions.
Government redlining meant that too often toxic waste dumps and polluting factories are located far away from white communities and right next to Black communities.

It’s time for our government to face this truth. Time for America to have a full-blown national conversation about reparations. Time to adopt H.R. 40, @JacksonLeeTX18’s reparations plan. Time to do what’s right, so our nation can begin to heal.
America was founded on principles of liberty and built on the backs of enslaved people.

This isn’t about drivers’ licenses or the Census. This is another cruel way that the Trump administration and Republicans are working to undercount, underfund, and take political power away from immigrant communities. We must fight back.

This is another example of a rigged and corrupt system. I’m fighting my heart out to put power in the hands of American workers.

Let’s be clear: It’s time for our government to have a full-blown national conversation about reparations. We must be honest about our history, and do what’s right so that our nation can begin to heal. #AtlantaWithWarren

White supremacy, white nationalism, and corruption threaten to break our democracy beyond repair. Now more than ever, all of us must embrace the lessons of Black history to confront this challenge. #AtlantaWithWarren

Racism props up the rich and powerful, leaving them free to take more power for themselves. And the rich and powerful aren’t going to just give away their power. If we want power, we have to fight for it. #AtlantaWithWarren

Yes, there’s a lot at stake in this election, and I know people are scared. But the washerwomen were not afraid. Dorothy Bolden was not afraid. I am not afraid. And you can't be afraid, either.  #AtlantaWithWarren
From the boldness of Atlanta’s Washerwomen to the courage of Dorothy Bolden, Black history teaches us that the only way to win is to get in the fight.
Dorothy Bolden showed that one very determined woman—backed up by many people across this country—can deliver big structural change.
This isn’t about whether or not we start a fight. We’re already in a fight. This is about how we win.

We all know—and say—the names of those whose lives have been cut short with callous indifference by law enforcement. Let’s honor Aiyana Stanley-Jones, Rekia Boyd, Korryn Gaines, Sandra Bland, and Atatiana Jefferson by reforming our criminal justice system once and for all.
And there’s more. It’s time to live our values. Look at the four words etched above the Supreme Court: Equal Justice Under Law. But justice is not equal in America.
Voter suppression is just one more relic of Jim Crow, and we need to say so. That’s why I have a plan to strengthen voting in America. It starts with restoring the Voting Rights Act.

Right now, our democracy is broken. How do I know? Because Brian Kemp is sitting in @StaceyAbrams’ chair. And we are all grateful to Stacey for what she’s doing to make sure that never happens again in this country.

The federal government helped create the racial divide in this country through decades of active, state-sponsored discrimination and that means the federal government has an obligation to fix it. And I have a lot of plans for how we can begin to fix it together.
The 1994 crime bill exacerbated the mass incarceration that has locked up millions of Black men and women, many for the smallest infractions.
Government redlining meant that too often toxic waste dumps and polluting factories are located far away from white communities and right next to Black communities.

It’s time for our government to face this truth. Time for America to have a full-blown national conversation about reparations. Time to adopt H.R. 40, @JacksonLeeTX18’s reparations plan. Time to do what’s right, so our nation can begin to heal.
America was founded on principles of liberty and built on the backs of enslaved people.
And now more than ever, all of us have to embrace the lessons of Black history. The rich and powerful aren’t going to just give away their power. No, if we want power, we have to fight for it!

But even in the face of racism, hatred, bigotry and corruption—Black history teaches us how to confront this moment of challenge. Black history teaches us how to stand up when we’re told to sit down, speak out when we’re told to be silent, march on even when the road gets rough.

The rich and powerful want us to be afraid of each other, because they’re afraid of us. Afraid of the people. Afraid of seeing us stand together. Afraid that we will take up each other’s fights as our own. Afraid that they will lose their power.

Divide and conquer is an old political tactic—and it comes in all sorts of ugly flavors: Racist, sexist, homophobic, transphobic, xenophobic. It’s the phobic—that’s the key part. It’s all about fear. Politics based in fear.

Today our government is working great for billionaires. Working great for giant corporations. Working great for those who cheerfully suck up as much wealth as they can, and never glance back at who gets left behind.

Donald Trump didn’t create this divide and conquer system. But he wouldn’t be in power without it. After eight years of progress under President Obama, Trump’s embrace of white supremacy, white nationalism, and corruption threaten to break our democracy beyond repair.
And when Black people won the fight to end school segregation and demanded federal funding for their children’s educations, poor white children got better educations, too.
When Black civil rights warriors won the fight for voting rights, voter turnout all across the South—for Blacks and whites—skyrocketed.

So, I want to speak directly to the question on some white people’s minds when we talk about the need to address what our government has done in Black communities. The uncomfortable question of “what will this mean for me”?
To this day racism still whispers the convenient lie to some white people that if your life has problems, you should blame “them”—people who don’t look like you.
Black history is American history. And American history teaches us that racism has for generations shaped every crucial aspect of our economy and political system.

Racist politicians doubled down. They divided Black people and white people in every moment of every day of every life, using force, violence, and intimidation to oppress Blacks and to ensure that Blacks and whites would never come together to stand up against those in power.
The law had promised equal civil and legal rights for all, and its loss was another body blow to our fragile, reconstructed democracy.

In 1883, two years after the successful washerwomen’s strike and as other groups were just beginning to exercise some political muscle, the Supreme Court struck down a civil rights law that had been passed in the wake of the Civil War.

But the gains were fleeting. As the idea that Black workers and white workers could make real structural change if they fought side by side began to spark to life, an evil force was once again mobilizing against it.
Then it happened. The employers, the city council, the powerful white citizens—they all backed down. The women won!

And when the City Council threatened to intervene, the women sent a public letter to the mayor of Atlanta and said they would not back down. They went right to the heart of the matter: “We mean business.”

Black women—then and now—are no strangers to facing resistance when they fight for justice, and Black women—then and now—don’t give up easy. Even in the face of imminent violence, Black women refused to be defined by fear. So, the women of the Washing Society persisted.
The employers struck back. They warned that they would use their money and power to start their own modern industrial laundry service to replace the washerwomen permanently.
In the space of three weeks, 20 women on strike became 200 women. And 200 women on strike became 2,000 women. 2,000 became 3,000.
And now more than ever, all of us have to embrace the lessons of Black history. The rich and powerful aren’t going to just give away their power. No, if we want power, we have to fight for it!

Then it happened. The employers, the city council, the powerful white citizens—they all backed down. The women won!

And when the City Council threatened to intervene, the women sent a public letter to the mayor of Atlanta and said they would not back down. They went right to the heart of the matter: “We mean business.”

Black women—then and now—are no strangers to facing resistance when they fight for justice, and Black women—then and now—don’t give up easy. Even in the face of imminent violence, Black women refused to be defined by fear. So, the women of the Washing Society persisted.
The employers struck back. They warned that they would use their money and power to start their own modern industrial laundry service to replace the washerwomen permanently.
In the space of three weeks, 20 women on strike became 200 women. And 200 women on strike became 2,000 women. 2,000 became 3,000.
One day, they had enough. It was July 1881, when 20 of Atlanta’s Black washerwomen threw down their washboards, walked away from their barrels—and formed a union: The Washing Society.
By nightfall, everything was folded and stacked, ready to be dropped off the next morning when they picked up a new pile of dirty laundry. And so the cycle continued—all for less than a dollar a day.

Black women and girls found that pretty much the only work white employers allowed them to do was the work that they’d been forced to do when they had been enslaved—caring for white families. Thousands of women scratched out a living as washerwomen. The work was heavy.
I want to tell a story. The year was 1881. After the tyranny of slavery, thousands of African Americans came to Atlanta hoping to build new lives, lives full of promise.

I’m here to make a commitment: When I am president of the United States, the lessons of Black history will not be lost. Those lessons, they will live in every part of my presidency—and I will ask you to hold me accountable for that promise every single day.

I wanted to stick around after last night’s debate because this city has been at the heart of America’s fight for justice. Atlanta is a city that honors fighters. The fighters I want to talk about tonight are Black women.

I’ve known @AyannaPressley for nearly a decade. Together, we've fought against for-profit colleges, stood for families torn apart by gun violence, and gone toe-to-toe with the Trump administration as we’ve fought to protect immigrant families. #AtlantaWithWarren
We're live at Clark Atlanta University—tune in! #AtlantaWithWarren

Donald Trump's racist immigration policies have done unimaginable harm, contributed to several deaths, and torn apart families. His proposed wall is a monument to hate and division. We must build a fair and humane immigration system that reflects our values—and I’ve got a plan.
See you soon!
Climate change is an existential threat—and unless we take urgent action to end this crisis, future generations will face catastrophic consequences. That's why I'm fighting for the #GreenNewDeal.
Big Tech companies are not doing enough to protect our privacy—and they won't until they face real competition and accountability.
Reproductive rights are economic rights. Reproductive rights are human rights. And I will fight for those rights for all people that need abortions.
Tell Bella that I say congrats, I AM so proud of her, and I’ll fight to make sure she has no student loan debt when she graduates!

Netanyahu is accused of accepting bribes, trading government favors, and manipulating a free press. Like his pal Donald Trump, he'll stop at nothing to enrich himself and stay in power. This blatant corruption has no place in any democracy—I'll fight it at home and abroad.

The way I see it, this is about our values. 

No American should ever die because they couldn't afford the care they need. No family should ever go broke because of health care costs. 

We need a health care system that reflects our values. That's #MedicareForAll.

Ambassador Gordon Sondland got his job after writing a $1 million check to Donald Trump's inaugural committee. This is Washington corruption at its worst. I've pledged never to give ambassadorial positions to wealthy donors—and every candidate should do the same.

Awood shows that when workers fight together, they can win. We have to protect and strengthen workers' rights to organize, make their voices heard, and hold giant corporations like Amazon accountable.

I won't cozy up to Facebook when I'm president. It's time to root out corruption in Washington. Until we do, we won't be able to make any progress on any of the issues that matter to us. And I've got a plan for that.

This is how the government keeps working for giant corporations and the wealthy and well-connected. It's no wonder that companies like Facebook have been allowed to consolidate economic and political power without any real accountability.

This is how the government keeps working for giant corporations and the wealthy and well-connected. It's no wonder that companies like Facebook have been allowed to consolidate economic and political power without any real accountability.

Amid antitrust scrutiny, Facebook is going on a charm offensive with Republican lawmakers. And now, Mark Zuckerberg and one of Facebook's board members—a major Trump donor—had a secret dinner with Trump. This is corruption, plain and simple.

We're not leaving yet, Atlanta! Join us at @CAU on Thursday, where I'll be sharing the stories of some of the most persistent and fearless fighters, Black women who proved that when working women fight together, they win. #AtlantaWithWarren

To everyone who tuned into the #DemDebate to cheer me on: Thank you!

I’m thankful for every #WarrenDemocrat who’s fighting for big, structural change. Will you donate $3 to our grassroots movement tonight? We can only do this together.

The issues we discussed at tonight’s #DemDebate touch people all over this country in their everyday lives. We know what we need to do. We have a lot of good ideas for how to fix things and a majority of Americans are with us. But we don't make change—because of corruption.

I believe that abortion rights are human rights.

I believe that they're also economic rights.

And protecting the right of a woman to be able to make decisions about her own body is fundamentally what we do and what we stand for as a Democratic Party. #DemDebate

I’m grateful to an America that gave the daughter of a janitor a chance to become a public school teacher, a college professor, a United States Senator, and a candidate for president of the United States. And I’ll fight my heart out so every kid has that chance, too. #DemDebate

I just stepped off the debate stage feeling inspired. #MedicareForAll, Universal Child Care, universal free college—it’s all possible if we fight for it. Pitch in whatever you can right now to own a part of our grassroots movement.

We have a lot of good ideas, yet we don't make change. Why not? Because of corruption. That’s why I have the biggest anti-corruption plan since Watergate. We have to have courage to tackle corruption head-on and fight for big, structural change. #DemDebate

In my first 100 days as president, I will open the doors to high-quality health care for millions of Americans. And when families compare that health care to fighting their insurance companies tooth and nail, the choice will be clear—we need #MedicareForAll. #DemDebate
I’m tired of freeloading billionaires. It's time for the top 1% to chip in their fair share so everyone has a chance to succeed. #DemDebate

Abortion rights are human rights and economic rights. If abortion is made illegal in America, rich women will still get them. It's just going to fall hard on poor women and women of color. I’ve got a plan to protect access to abortion no matter what SCOTUS does. #DemDebate

When I found out our government was tearing families apart, I went to a detention center at the border. It was like a giant Amazon warehouse of women, babies, and children in cages. We must treat immigrants with dignity and live our values at the border every day. #DemDebate

Right now, Black Americans are more likely to borrow money for college and have a harder time paying off student loan debt. My plan to cancel student loan debt is a tangible and real way to help close the racial wealth gap. #DemDebate

We need to ensure that everyone in this country has the opportunity to succeed. Here's what we could do with my two-cent #WealthTax:
✅ Universal Child Care and pre-k
✅ $800 billion dollars in our public schools
✅ $50 billion in HBCUs
✅ Cancel student loan debt
#DemDebate

Our defense budget is massively bloated—we need to end the cozy relationship between defense contractors and the Pentagon, then pull out a sharp knife and make real cuts. I've got a plan for that. #DemDebate

All three of my brothers served, so I know the responsibility our country has toward military personnel and their families. And I’ve got a plan to honor our promises to our nation’s veterans, service members, military families, and survivors. #DemDebate

For decades, racist redlining practices blocked Black and Brown families from home ownership and building wealth. My housing plan helps level the playing field for families who were denied wealth-building opportunities. #DemDebate

Child care is personal for me. My #UniversalChildCare plan guarantees high-quality child care and early education for every child. It’ll be free for millions of families, and affordable for all. Use my calculator to see how much your family would save:
Billionaires should pitch in a little more so that every family can have a shot at the American dream.

Tens of millions of Americans have skipped appointments or medications because they can’t afford it. As president, I’ll reverse Trump’s sabotage of the ACA, lower prices for drugs like insulin, lower the Medicare age to 50, and bring 135 million Americans into #MedicareForAll.

Amid antitrust scrutiny, Facebook is going on a charm offensive with Republican lawmakers. And now, Mark Zuckerberg and one of Facebook's board members—a major Trump donor—had a secret dinner with Trump. This is corruption, plain and simple.

We're not leaving yet, Atlanta! Join us at @CAU on Thursday, where I'll be sharing the stories of some of the most persistent and fearless fighters, Black women who proved that when working women fight together, they win. #AtlantaWithWarren

My #WealthTax asks them to pitch in a little more, so that every family can have a shot at the American dream. #DemDebate

Let me tell you what we can do with my #WealthTax:

✔️ Universal Child Care
✔️ Universal pre-k
✔️ $800 billion dollars into our public schools
✔️ $50 billion to #HBCUs
✔️ Cancel student loan debt 

#DemDebate

My #WealthTax says: When you make it big, pitch in two cents so that everyone else can make it too. Regardless of party affiliation, our country is working better for the rich and powerful, and worse for everyone else. We need to make our economy work for everyone. #DemDebate

The way we achieve our goals and bring our country together is by talking about the things that unite us. We want to make this country work for all of us—not just the rich and the powerful. #DemDebate

The Mueller report shows how Donald Trump tried to obstruct justice and break the law—again and again and again. That's what's happened with Ukraine. No one is above the law, not even the president of the United States. #DemDebate

Today’s hearing makes me wonder how Ambassador Sondland got there. This is not a man who had any qualifications except one: He wrote a check for a million dollars. In a Warren administration, we’re not going to give away ambassador posts to the highest bidder. #DemDebate

Politicians are supposed to compete over how many voters they can persuade, not how many they can disqualify or demoralize. I stand with @StaceyAbrams—and that's why I have a plan to guarantee the right to vote and end voter suppression.

I had a wonderful time meeting Lily and her friend Jenny. Lily donated just $10 and won the @TeamWarren contest to join me at tonight's #DemDebate in Atlanta! Thank you both for being a part of this grassroots movement.

I called @AdyBarkan to tell him that I'm so grateful to have him on @TeamWarren. I'm going to fight for Ady, Rachael, Carl, and Willow just as hard as I fight for my own family. We're going to make big, structural change, together.

Donald Trump is the most corrupt president in our lifetimes. In a Warren administration, we’ll root out Washington corruption once and for all.

Will you chip in $3 before the #DemDebate tonight to help our campaign keep fighting?

Desde aumentar el salario mínimo federal hasta combatir la discriminación sistémica y proteger el derecho de las trabajadoras latinas a sindicalizarse: estoy lista para luchar desde el primer día para cerrar la brecha salarial. #LatinaEqualPayDay

It's long past time to close the Latina pay gap, and I've got a plan for that. From raising the federal minimum wage, to fighting systemic discrimination, to protecting Latina workers’ rights to unionize—I'm ready to fight on day one. #LatinaEqualPayDay

37 million Americans didn’t fill a prescription because of costs. 
36 million skipped a recommended test or treatment because of costs. 
40 million didn’t go to a doctor to check out a health problem because of costs.
This should never happen. It's time for #MedicareForAll.
On Transgender Day of Remembrance, we #SayTheirNames, and we re-commit to ending this epidemic. #TDoR

I’m fighting my heart out for Rachael, for Carl, for baby Willow—and for you, @AdyBarkan.

(P.S. Willow: Your dad is an inspiration. I’m so honored to know him, and to fight alongside him for a better future for all.)

We wouldn't be this far in the fight for #MedicareForAll without activists like @AdyBarkan, who has given his life to ensure that every American gets the medical care they need. I’m grateful down to my toes to be in this fight alongside you, Ady.

White nationalist violence is a domestic terrorism threat—and we must treat it like one. I've got a plan to fight white nationalist violence. And when I'm president, combating white nationalist crime will be a top priority for the Departments of Justice and Homeland Security.

I'm standing with the Indiana teachers rallying for their schools. We need to invest in public education and our public school teachers. They're fighting for our students, so we should be fighting for them, too. #RedForEd

We are facing a Black maternal mortality crisis in America. This is life and death for too many moms and babies. I've got a plan to end this epidemic. Thank you @NVPartnersLV and @StevenHorsford for welcoming me to the Black Community Summit.
White nationalism has no place in our country, our White House, or our Congress. Let's start by getting Steve King out of office and electing @JDScholten to replace him. #IA04

Politicians are supposed to compete over how many voters they can persuade, not how many they can disqualify or demoralize. I stand with @StaceyAbrams—and that's why I have a plan to guarantee the right to vote and end voter suppression.

I had a wonderful time meeting Lily and her friend Jenny. Lily donated just $10 and won the @TeamWarren contest to join me at tonight's #DemDebate in Atlanta! Thank you both for being a part of this grassroots movement.

I called @AdyBarkan to tell him that I'm so grateful to have him on @TeamWarren. I'm going to fight for Ady, Rachael, Carl, and Willow just as hard as I fight for my own family. We're going to make big, structural change, together.

Donald Trump is the most corrupt president in our lifetimes. In a Warren administration, we’ll root out Washington corruption once and for all.

Will you chip in $3 before the #DemDebate tonight to help our campaign keep fighting?

Desde aumentar el salario mínimo federal hasta combatir la discriminación sistémica y proteger el derecho de las trabajadoras latinas a sindicalizarse: estoy lista para luchar desde el primer día para cerrar la brecha salarial. #LatinaEqualPayDay

It's long past time to close the Latina pay gap, and I've got a plan for that. From raising the federal minimum wage, to fighting systemic discrimination, to protecting Latina workers’ rights to unionize—I'm ready to fight on day one. #LatinaEqualPayDay

37 million Americans didn’t fill a prescription because of costs. 
36 million skipped a recommended test or treatment because of costs. 
40 million didn’t go to a doctor to check out a health problem because of costs.
This should never happen. It's time for #MedicareForAll.
On Transgender Day of Remembrance, we #SayTheirNames, and we re-commit to ending this epidemic. #TDoR

I’m fighting my heart out for Rachael, for Carl, for baby Willow—and for you, @AdyBarkan.

(P.S. Willow: Your dad is an inspiration. I’m so honored to know him, and to fight alongside him for a better future for all.)

We wouldn't be this far in the fight for #MedicareForAll without activists like @AdyBarkan, who has given his life to ensure that every American gets the medical care they need. I’m grateful down to my toes to be in this fight alongside you, Ady.

White nationalist violence is a domestic terrorism threat—and we must treat it like one. I've got a plan to fight white nationalist violence. And when I'm president, combating white nationalist crime will be a top priority for the Departments of Justice and Homeland Security.

I'm standing with the Indiana teachers rallying for their schools. We need to invest in public education and our public school teachers. They're fighting for our students, so we should be fighting for them, too. #RedForEd

We are facing a Black maternal mortality crisis in America. This is life and death for too many moms and babies. I've got a plan to end this epidemic. Thank you @NVPartnersLV and @StevenHorsford for welcoming me to the Black Community Summit.
White nationalism has no place in our country, our White House, or our Congress. Let's start by getting Steve King out of office and electing @JDScholten to replace him. #IA04
I'm proud to fight alongside @AyannaPressley for the big, structural change we need—and so happy to announce that she'll be one of my special guests for my speech in Atlanta on Thursday!

From the Triangle Shirtwaist Factory to the Atlanta Washerwomen Strike, history has proven that when working women fight together, they win. Hear @rgay share that story—and then join me in Atlanta on Thursday, where I'll be sharing how we can put power in the hands of the people.

Our alliances are not charity or protection rackets. They enhance our security and promote our values. Storming out of a negotiation may be good TV, but it undermines our interests and our long history of friendship with South Korea and Japan.

I introduced a bill for a national ban on so-called "right-to-work" laws that undermine workers and unions—but Virginia has the opportunity to repeal their "right-to-work" law now. They shouldn't hesitate to support unions and working families.
We need to put power back where it belongs: With tenants, not big corporate landlords. As president, I’ll also fight for a nationwide right-to-counsel for low- and middle-income tenants.

Ultimately, this is about our values. I’ve seen up close and personal how devastating a diagnosis can be—and how the bills can turn people’s lives upside down. When I’m president, I’m going to do everything in my power to make sure that never happens to another family again.

Finally, I'll work with states to expand their Medicaid programs, helping them enroll uninsured people who are already eligible for Medicaid and helping them increase eligibility. We can cover 18 million more Americans with Medicaid—all without Congress.

I will take action on day one to slash drug prices for critical drugs like Insulin, EpiPens, PrEP, and more—relieving tens of millions of Americans from the crushing prices they pay at the pharmacy each month. No more cutting pills, rationing, or skipping doses.

My plan will improve Medicare for the nearly 60 million seniors who are currently enrolled, adding dental, vision, audio, and long-term care coverage. And I'll lower the Medicare age to 50, giving 57 million more Americans a chance to enroll.

First, my plan gives every child and everyone making at or below 200% of the Federal Poverty Level the opportunity to enroll in free health care coverage through a #MedicareForAll option. That’s a total of nearly 135 million Americans who could get free, high-quality coverage.

#MedicareForAll is the best way to cover every person in America at the lowest possible cost. I've laid out my plan to pay for it and how to get us there in my first term. Here’s how I would reduce health care costs for millions in my first 100 days.

Stephen Miller's white nationalism has no place in the White House. He must resign. 

We need a president who takes the threat of white nationalism seriously. I have a plan—and I'll start by reversing Trump and Miller's racist policies.

Donald Trump wants to divide us and pit us against each other. He wants Americans to blame their troubles on those who seem different, even as his administration robs us dry. But America can be better than that. To take on hate, we all have to stand up against it—together.

Finally, I'll work to build and rebuild trust in communities impacted by white nationalist violence. My administration will work with local leaders to combat hate, build resilience, and strengthen their communities.

I’ll establish a zero-tolerance policy for any federal law enforcement officer who participates in white nationalist crimes. And my plan for police reform would replace failed policies with effective, evidence-based practices that don't violate individual rights.

Communities targeted by white nationalists are essential partners in the effort to combat this threat, yet they often lack trust in law enforcement. Survivors and witnesses need to feel comfortable coming forward so perpetrators of hate crimes can be held accountable.

Any strategy to combat white nationalist crime must be proactive, addressing racism and intolerance before it has a chance to grow. I'll invest in early interventions to protect our children from extremist violence.

Too often, guns are used in acts of domestic terrorism. Over 10,300 hate crimes are committed using a gun each year on average. We need to expand background checks and keep guns out of the hands of those who may be violent or who have been convicted of hate crimes.

We have the laws to combat white nationalist crimes. What we lack is the will to prioritize investigating and prosecuting these crimes. In a Warren administration, combating white nationalist crime will be a top priority for the Departments of Justice and Homeland Security.

We’ve all seen the consequences. Hate crimes spiked after Trump’s election, and last year violent personal attacks reached a 16-year high. It's clear that racists, white supremacists, and people with hateful ideologies feel empowered by this president.

We’ve all seen the consequences. Hate crimes spiked after Trump’s election, and last year violent personal attacks reached a 16-year high. It's clear that racists, white supremacists, and people with hateful ideologies feel empowered by this president.

But the current administration has chosen to ignore the threat posed by white nationalists and violent extremists. Donald Trump has cozied up to white nationalists—even hiring some into his White House. He's made one racist remark after another and put in place racist policies.

Mother Emanuel AME Church.
Charlottesville.
Tree of Life Synagogue.
El Paso.
Unfortunately, these aren't isolated tragedies. The FBI logged over 7,000 hate crimes last year, and there are likely hundreds of thousands more that go unreported or uncategorized.

The Trump administration has ignored the threat posed by white nationalists and violent extremists—and Trump himself has stoked the flames. In a Warren administration, we will use every tool we have to defeat domestic terrorism. Here's my plan:

Millions of Americans are spending more than 30% of their income on rent. I’ve got a plan to make housing more affordable, protect renters from unjust eviction and discrimination, and invest in healthy and green homes. 

Everyone deserves a safe, affordable place to live.
The way I see it, this election is about fighting for the big ideas that reflect our values. 2020 is our time to dream big, fight hard, and win!

Everyone deserves a safe, affordable place to live—and I'm committed to fighting to protect tenants’ rights. Thank you @MakeRoadActNV and @CPDAction for joining me today to discuss my plan to protect and empower renting families!
The forceful removal of @NJWFA State Director @SueAltman from a public hearing is outrageous. I stand with her and @WorkingFamilies.

Black and Brown students are more likely to be punished in school—and they're more likely to be arrested for minor infractions. Enough is enough. No student should have to learn in an environment where there is a threat of incarceration.

Doug Manchester is just the tip of the iceberg. Donald Trump has perfected the act of selling swanky diplomatic posts to his rich buddies. It's corruption, plain and simple. I've pledged to end the practice of giving ambassadorial posts to wealthy donors.

The CFPB protects consumers from Big Banks, Wall Street, and predatory lenders. We need a Tenant Protection Bureau to enforce tenants’ rights, take on bad actors, and make sure landlords keep affordable housing available for working families.

Another blatantly ideological attempt by the Trump administration to distract from its failures in the region. Not only do these settlements violate international law—they make peace harder to achieve. As president, I will reverse this policy and pursue a two state solution.

Attorneys General stand on the front lines of the fight to protect access to abortion and reproductive rights—and I stand with @DemocraticAGs. Thank you for making this commitment to defend our rights.

The Bolivian people deserve free and fair elections, as soon as possible. Bolivia's interim leadership must limit itself to preparing for an early, legitimate election. Bolivia's security forces must protect demonstrators, not commit violence against them.

The #GreenNewDeal isn't just about fighting climate change. It's about fighting for environmental and economic justice. American workers can lead the global effort to end the climate crisis, build a green new economy, and create more than a million good jobs here at home.

We shouldn't have to live like this. The daily toll of gun violence is staggering. From Walmart to our schools, our streets, our playgrounds, our houses of worship—no place is safe from it. It's time to end gun violence.
From flipping seats to building the first majority-woman state legislature, @NVDems are growing the momentum that will help Democrats win big in 2020! #FirstInTheWest

My plan to rein in Wall Street will hold private equity firms accountable. And I’ll stop federal dollars from going to predatory landlords and lenders with a history of harassing tenants, forcing tenants to live in dangerous or indecent conditions, or redlining our communities.

We must invest in safe, healthy, and green public housing. I’ll push for investments in new public housing construction. And I’ll fight to close the repair backlog, expand disability accessibility, and for 1:1 replacement of any units that have to be removed or demolished.

Everyone in America should have a decent, affordable, and safe place to live. We need to tackle our housing crisis head-on—and I'm ready to fight for the big, structural change renting families need.

My plan to rein in Wall Street will hold private equity firms accountable. And I’ll stop federal dollars from going to predatory landlords and lenders with a history of harassing tenants, forcing tenants to live in dangerous or indecent conditions, or redlining our communities.

Finally, I'll fight exploitation by corporate landlords. Private equity firms have become some of our country’s biggest landlords—snatching up properties, raising rents, evicting tenants, and spending millions lobbying against tenant protection legislation.

We must invest in safe, healthy, and green public housing. I’ll push for investments in new public housing construction. And I’ll fight to close the repair backlog, expand disability accessibility, and for 1:1 replacement of any units that have to be removed or demolished.

Next, we'll tackle skyrocketing rent costs. My administration will stop states from preempting local tenant protection laws, including rent control, by denying access to billions of dollars in federal grants to states who maintain those laws.

I’ll work to secure tenants’ rights nationwide. And I’ll also push to create a new Tenant Protection Bureau—modeled after the CFPB—to enforce tenants’ rights, take on bad actors, and make sure landlords keep affordable housing within reach for working families.

My plan starts with protecting and upholding the rights of tenants. Landlords shouldn’t be able to arbitrarily push families out of their communities to make an extra buck, or because of thinly-veiled racism and discrimination.

Stagnant wages, sky-rocketing rents, and a stark shortage of affordable options are squeezing America's renting households. Gentrification is displacing communities of color, landlords are exploiting their power over tenants, and Wall Street is snapping up apartment complexes.

My housing plan will invest $500 billion into building, preserving, and restoring more than 3 million units and create 1.5 million jobs. Today, I'm expanding on those efforts with my plan to protect and empower renters.
My plan to pay for #MedicareForAll will cover everyone, cost less, and put $11 trillion back in the pockets of American families. And no family will ever go broke because of health care costs again.
I'm not afraid to fight for the big, structural change we need—and I know North Las Vegas isn't afraid, either!
I'm proud to stand alongside the dedicated activists, survivors, and family members fighting gun violence in Nevada. Together, we can tackle corruption in Washington and end gun violence.

If we want to make big, structural change, we need to keep growing @TeamWarren. Will you donate $3 or more to our campaign? With less than 90 days until the Iowa caucuses, this is an important moment for our grassroots movement.
Thank you, Cedar Rapids! I know that if we dream big and fight hard, we can win.

Traffic violence kills thousands and injures even more Americans every year. On World Day of Remembrance for Traffic Crash Victims, I'm sending my love to the families and friends of those who have lost loved ones. It's time to #EndTrafficViolence.
Trump's tax cut was always just another giveaway for his rich buddies and wealthy donors—and it's working exactly as it‘s supposed to. It's corruption, plain and simple.

You're probably paying more in federal income taxes than a bunch of big American corporations that make billions of dollars. It's obscene. These companies love to wave the American flag, but they won’t pitch in a dime to support the investments we make.
The billionaires can whine all they want. That won’t stop us from fighting for big, structural change to make our economy work for the people.

We hear a lot of crying from billionaires about my #WealthTax that will make them slightly less outrageously wealthy. I want to hear more from the families whose lives would be transformed by universal child care and student loan debt cancellation.

The Chinese government’s cruel, bigoted treatment of Muslims and ethnic minorities is a horrifying human rights violation.

We must stand up to hatred and extremism at home—and around the world.
Saturday walk with my guy.

Unfortunately, @TaylorSwift13 is one of many whose work has been threatened by a private equity firm. They're gobbling up more and more of our economy, costing jobs and crushing entire industries. It's time to rein in private equity firms—and I've got a plan for that.
Google bought small competitors in order to consolidate their power—and now, they're abusing it. No company should have this much power. It's time to #BreakUpBigTech.

No more rationing insulin. No more cutting pills. No more going without. On day one as president, I'll immediately act to lower the cost of prescription drugs. And by the end of my first term, we'll move to fully transition to #MedicareForAll.

Harvoni is described as a "miracle" drug, but it's $94,500-per-treatment price tag leaves 85% of the more than 3 million Americans living with Hepatitis C unable to use it, while taxpayers foot a $3.8 billion bill.

Truvada’s manufacturer, Gilead, relied on $50 million in federal grants to develop it, but today they rake in multi-billion dollar profits while Americans struggle to afford it. Only a fraction of patients benefit from it, thanks to its hefty $2,000-a-month price tag.

Humira is used by millions of patients around the world to treat diseases like arthritis, psoriasis, and Crohn’s disease. But its manufacturer, AbbVie, doubled its price—and used blatantly anti-competitive behavior to prevent a competitor from entering the market.

Health officials agree that naloxone is critical to curbing the opioid epidemic, and it can be as cheap as 5¢ a dose. But one company spiked the price of their product by over 550% to “capitalize on the opportunity” of the opioid crisis.

EpiPens deliver life-saving doses of epinephrine, a drug that reverses severe allergic reactions to things like peanuts and bee stings. In 2016, EpiPens’ manufacturer jacked up prices by 400%, leaving families unable to afford this life-saving medication.

Insulin was discovered nearly 100 years ago as a treatment for diabetes. But three drug companies dominated the market and jacked up prices. Now, Americans with diabetes are rationing their insulin—and taxpayers are spending billions on it through Medicare and Medicaid.

Prescription drug companies' obscene price gouging is leaving patients without access to lifesaving medical treatments. I've got a plan to lower costs on several key drugs that millions rely on. Here are just a few examples.

Donald Trump is hollowing out our State Department and undermining our ambassadors—putting our diplomacy efforts in grave danger. We'll need to rebuild our State Department, and I have a plan for that.
I'm going to fight my heart out for #MedicareForAll—and here's how I'll get us there in my first term.

37 million Americans didn't fill a prescription last year because of costs. Within my first 100 days as president, I will act to lower the cost of essential medications like insulin, EpiPens, and naloxone.

Millions of Americans will experience the full benefits of a #MedicareForAll option and see how it compares to high-priced coverage and fighting their insurance company tooth and nail. And when we move to complete the transition to #MedicareForAll, the choice will be clear.
And I'll give every American over the age of 50 the choice to enter into a substantially improved Medicare program.

This option will include all of the health care benefits of #MedicareForAll, including primary and preventive services, pediatric care, emergency services and transportation, vision, dental, audio, long-term care, mental health and substance use, and physical therapy.

In my first 100 days, I'll fight to create a true #MedicareForAll option that will be immediately free for millions of  Americans, including children under the age of 18 and families making at or below 200% of the federal poverty level.
Thank you, @PramilaJayapal. You've been doing incredible work in the House and have kept the momentum moving forward. I’m honored to keep working alongside you for #MedicareForAll!

No one should have to ration their medication or skip filling it because of the cost. As president, I will act immediately to lower the cost of prescription drugs—and I'll fight my heart out for #MedicareForAll.
I hope I'll see you at Clark Atlanta University on November 21!

This is how Wall Street's corrupt grip on Washington will end. Not with a bang, but with the tears of some sad billionaires—who will still be unimaginably rich, but will have paid their fair share so America could cancel student loan debt, have universal child care, and more.

Billionaires like Blankfein can say whatever they want, but I've spent my career holding big banks accountable and fighting for working families—and I'm going to keep building a movement to make America work for working families.
